Piazza Post:0
Poster:student
Num Views:0
Type:note
Created:2014-08-10T12:58:26Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Welcome to Piazza!
Content: Piazza is a Q&amp;A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started: 1. Ask questions! The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are). 2. Edit questions and answers wiki-style. Think of Piazza as a Q&amp;A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single students' answer that students can edit collectively (and a single instructors&#8217; answer for instructors). 3. Add a followup to comment or ask further questions. To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a followup discussion. Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&amp;A above. 4. Go anonymous. Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously. 5. Tag your posts. It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a &#8220;#&#8221; before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag. 6. Format code and equations. Adding a code snippet? Click the pre or tt button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. Mathematical equation? Click the Fx button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation. 7. View and download class details and resources. Click the Course Page button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources&#8212;all in one place! Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at team@piazza.com. We love feedback!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:9
Poster:instructor
Num Views:316
Type:note
Created:2014-08-10T13:21:58Z
Tags:no_history, other, pin
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:HOW TO USE PIAZZA
Content:Welcome to 183 on Piazza! We'll be conducting all class-related discussion here this term. The quicker you begin asking questions on Piazza (rather than via emails), the quicker you'll benefit from the collective knowledge of your classmates and instructors. We encourage you to ask questions when you're struggling to understand a concept&#8212;you can even do so anonymously. Guidelines for using Piazza: Search Always search for your question topic before you post. Piazza centers around the idea of building a single question and answer thread for each specific topic, resulting in less total posts (easier to search and browse) and more information in one place for those seeking help. Similar question? Follow up If there is a related question, but it is not exactly your question please post it as a followup question so other students can easily find the help they need. If questions are very similar, you can link between them with the '@' symbol: for example, @6 Use a clear topic for your post The more specific your topic is, the easier it is for others to find your post if they have the same question. Give context If you're posting about Codelab, Zyante or a practice exam, please include the question's number and the full prompt in your post. Add tags and folders If you are asking a questions about project 3, add the "project3" folder to your post. This makes it easier for others to find the discussion. Return the favor Know the answer to a question? Help others out by contributing to the Student Answer. Show your support Like someone's answer? Click "good answer" to show your approval! Don't post code Posting or sharing actual code is a violation of the Engineering Honor Code. Offending posts will be removed. - The 183 Staff <link> Course Website 183 Course Policies Engineering Honor Code Proper Use of Information Resources #pin
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:10
Poster:instructor
Num Views:381
Type:note
Created:2014-09-03T07:36:05Z
Tags:logistics
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Announcement: Welcome to 183
Content:It's finally here! 183 begins today. We're excited to bring you one of the highest-quality and fastest-growing courses on campus, and we're working overtime - <link> seriously, we're working right now - to make it better than ever before. Many of you have been tracking the countdown to opening day on the course website, and it's my pleasure to announce that <link> umich.edu/~eecs183 is now open and available for your use. Here's a brief overview of the resources available to you on the site. You'll become well acquainted with all of these over the next weeks. 1. Piazza - Piazza is our online help forum. It allows students and instructors to cooperatively construct the best questions and the best answers for the benefit of all. We'll be conducting all discussions related to the course on Piazza this term, and all announcements will be released on our Piazza page, although for backwards compatibility we'll also post announcements on CTools. You can reach Piazza via the bright blue button on the website. 2. Zyante - Zyante is our online textbook. You'll complete weekly reading assignments on Zyante which should ideally be completed before coming to class each week. We'll grade you simply based on completion of the reading. You'll need to register for it (instructions can be found <link> here), and you can reach Zyante via the bright orange button on our website. 3. CodeLab - CodeLab is our online "practice zone". It contains a large number of short practice questions which will serve as a supplement to your lecture and textbook materials. You'll complete it in segments over the course of the semester, and we'll grade you solely based on the number of questions completed. As with Zyante, you'll need to register (instructions for Zyante registration can be found <link> here), and you can reach CodeLab via the bright green button on our website. From the website you can also access the <link> autograder, the <link> office hours signup list, our <link> 183 style checker, the <link> syllabus, <link> course calendar and all of the resources (lecture slides, taped lecture recordings, discussion slides, and much more) available to you in this course. We look forward to seeing you tomorrow, and wish you only the very best in your experience this semester. - The 183 Staff
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:46
Poster:student
Num Views:77
Type:question
Created:2014-09-04T20:48:14Z
Tags:codelab
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Entering wrong answer in codelab
Content:Are we deducted points for submitting a wrong answer in CodeLab? or will it tell us that the submission is wrong and prompt us to edit it until it is correct? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:47
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-04T21:03:28Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:46
Subject:
Content:When you get a question wrong on CodeLab, it prompts you again until you answer the question correctly. You are given points based on how many you have correct at the deadline; or in other words, you have an infinite number of tries before the deadline to get it correct. If it is incorrect at the deadline, you will fail to receive points for that question. If you so choose, CodeLab allows you to skip problems wholly or for you to skip problems that you cannot figure out. Of course, this is not recommended.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This time I am getting the following errors. Debug Error- <image> Build Error - <image> Any thoughts? ---------------------------------------- The first 10 lines are simply the comments line that was provided in the base code. Simply all that was changed in the code from what was provided was filling out the admin information on the comments and adding the following command under the main. int main() { cout << "test"; return 0; } The includes and namespaces remain the same. #include <iostream> #include <cmath> #include <string> using namespace std; Which when creating a new project and only have those two blocks of code, I can run it just fine. Piazza Post:57
Poster:student
Num Views:26
Type:question
Created:2014-09-05T05:05:36Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Xcode
Content:Hello, if you are running Yosemite Beta on your mac, would it be better to downgrade back to mavericks to use xcode 5 or use the xcode 6 beta? Thank you.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:58
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-05T05:18:08Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:57
Subject:
Content:That's kind of subjective. The beta has some cool new stuff, but Xcode 5 is more "stable" because people have been using it longer, meaning less bugs remain. Even if you have Yosemite installed, you can still download Xcode 5 from the Mac App Store. In fact, you can have both Xcode 5 and Xcode 6 installed at the same time. I've found a few bugs in Xcode 6, which might cause some unexpected crashes and inconsistencies.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:60

Piazza Post:62
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-05T15:38:54Z
Tags:
Endorsements:4
Response To:61
Subject:
Content:You have unlimited submits to the style grader. Daily submits are how many submits you get per day with feedback. The final submit is the very last submission of your project. Yes you have unlimited submits to the style checker. And yes please use it. There are only repercussions if you don't and your style is awful.

Piazza Post:69
Poster:student
Num Views:67
Type:question
Created:2014-09-06T16:38:43Z
Tags:zyante
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:cin vs cout
Content:What's the difference between cin and cout? thanks
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:70
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-06T17:06:07Z
Tags:
Endorsements:4
Response To:69
Subject:
Content:cout outputs whatever you place after the <<, such as text (in double quotations) or variables that you assigned values beforehand. It basically prints it out on the screen. cin uses the user's input to define a certain variable's value. Assume that the program wanted the user to enter how much their hourly wage is. Afterward, if you use cin, the program will input that hourly wage value into a variable that you make. --- You can imagine it like this: I am sending strings "out" onto the screen (cout), so the arrows towards cout. cout << "Sending string to screen...."; On the other hand: I want to receive information from the user, so I want to send the information I receive into" a variable (cin), so the arrows point towards the variable. int var; cin >> var; If you're a visual learner, imagine cout and cin to be two one-way cables leading to and from the monitor. Of course, that isn't actually the case, but it should serve as a decent metaphor for what cout and cin does. At least, for now.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:76
Poster:student
Num Views:59
Type:question
Created:2014-09-06T18:23:09Z
Tags:zyante
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:variable definitions and assignment statements
Content:What is the difference between variable definitions and assignment statements? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:77
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-06T18:31:59Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:76
Subject:
Content:The assignment statement uses the assignment operator ( = ) to assign an expression to the variable. For example, int dog = 4*5; . A variable declaration just lets you know what the type is. For example, int dog; . dog is a variable name for an integer that can be assigned later.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:78
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-06T18:48:41Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:76
Subject:
Content:I will assume that when you said "variable definitions," you meant "declaring variables". There are four parts to the following code: int num = 10; int - the type of variable you are declaring. num - the name by which you'll be referring to the variable henceforth. These two things are all you need when declaring (creating) a variable. = - the symbol denoting that you will be assigning the variable num. 10 - the int value you are assigning to num. This second half of the code above is how you assign values, strings, or whatever data types you want to a corresponding variable. In that sense, both of the codes accomplish the same thing. int num = 125; int num; num = 125; I've only divided up the two steps of declaring a variable and assigning a variable.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Can we work together on this project or not?
Content:Will we know when we can or can't help each other learn on assignments?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:86
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-07T01:12:07Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:85
Subject:
Content:It will be made very clear when you are allowed to have a partner on a project. For this project, the answer is no, no partners. As for helping each other learn more generally, the answer is a little more nuanced. In general, you should really try to keep to yourself on assignments. The consequences for cheating are quite harsh and not something you want to have to deal with. As an imperfect rule of thumb, you can talk about concepts and study for exams together but it's best if you keep to yourself as far as code (except for your partner, once partners are allowed).
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:87
Poster:instructor
Num Views:52
Type:question
Created:2014-09-07T06:01:56Z
Tags:project1, no_history
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:String Pluralize
Content:Hello, I just cannot figure out how to get the string pluralize function to work. This is what I have: string pluralize(string single, string plural, int number); int main() { int numGuests = 25; //User input: how many guests int numBatches = 0; cout << "How many people do you need to serve? " << <removed by 183Staff> << endl; cout << endl; // removed by 183 Staff cout << "You need to make: " << <removed by 183Staff> << " batch of cupcakes" << endl; return 0; } string pluralize(string single, string plural, int number) { if (number == 1) { return single; } return plural; } It compiles fine but I do not understand what I need to type to get "batch" when numBatches = 1 and "batches" when numBatches = any other number. Thanks,
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:88
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-07T06:30:10Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:87
Subject:
Content:We will be discussing this in much more detail later, but here is a hint that will hopefully get you moving in the right direction without stepping on the lecture's toes too much. When you say: cout << "batch" The string "batch" will print every time, simple as that. In the code you've pasted above, which by the way is generally a Piazza no-no unless it's 100% code we gave to you, what you have is just the definition of the pluralize() function. In order to actually make use of it, you'll have to accumulate the result of a call to this function with the proper arguments to your desired output stream.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Endorsements:0
Response To:112
Subject:After Mon and Wed lecture of this week, and discussion section this week, you should feel far more confident in how to begin Project 1. But you certainly can begin reading the spec and thinking about how to do the conversions (intuitively). Worry about code later.

Piazza Post:115
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-08T14:44:58Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:112
Subject:
Content:There is a wide, and I really do mean wide, range of experience and non-experience among EECS 183 students concerning programming and computer science in general. However, the number of people who are very familiar with or are very fast learners are undoubtedly a very small minority, so don't feel left out or behind just yet! For example, I heard a friend of mine from high school (local school) is also taking this course, and he has experience writing programs for certain companies. @_@ On the other hand, another friend of mine (also from local) is taking this course, and they haven't the slightest clue how to write code. And judging by statistics and the surveys taken, there is way, way more of the latter than the former. Of course, it's a little intimidating seeing someone finish a project that requires information and concepts that haven't even been introduced to us yet, but they're the abnormal in this case, so no need to worry. :)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:154
Poster:student
Num Views:115
Type:question
Created:2014-09-08T15:22:28Z
Tags:logistics, other, project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Multiple cout functions in a row vs. one extended cout function? (style question)
Content:Style question: When using several cout functions (such as printing the shopping list in project 1) is it better to write several cout functions in a row for organization purposes, or have one long cout function cut up into many lines? For example: cout << "string" << endl; << "second string" << endl; << "third string" << variableName << endl; And so on.... 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:155
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-08T15:30:30Z
Tags:
Endorsements:3
Response To:154
Subject:
Content:Better to do it all as one, broken up as you have it. It has to do with optimization, and is a little out of the scope of the class. But also note that if you have the semicolons on the end of all of the lines, your code won't run. You need: cout << "string" << endl << "next string" << endl << "last one" << endl; Semicolons go on the end of statements, so if you use the cout as one big statement, you only want it on the end.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:156
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-08T15:45:48Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:154
Subject:Would a constant name such as COST_CNTNR_SOURCRM or COST_BAG_POWD_SUGAR be considered excessively long names for constants? I am having issues trying to condense some of my constant names for Project 1. 
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:157
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-08T15:51:53Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:154
Subject:Those aren't excessively long, but they are pretty long. The idea behind having descriptive names is so that if someone else came and read your code, they would easily be able to identify what the variable stands for. In this case, since you only have one sour cream cost variable, you could just say COST_SOUR_CREAM instead of shrinking cream and container. When we say excessively long names we meant more like COST_OF_CONTAINER_OF_SOUR_CREAM_IN_AMERICAN_DOLLARS_AND_CENTS. That would be excessive
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:158
Poster:student

Piazza Post:160
Poster:student
Num Views:11
Type:question
Created:2014-09-08T15:29:28Z
Tags:other
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:<< endl
Content:What does "cout << "Hello, World" << endl" do compared to "cout << "Hello, World" << endl <<endl"?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:161
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-08T15:32:17Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:160
Subject:
Content:There was an extra blank row of text between the output and the ending text "Program ended with exit code: 0" when you put in two endl.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:162
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-08T15:34:30Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:160
Subject:
Content:Having two endls would put two endlines on your output, and the best way to illustrate it would be to add another cout after. Heres an example: cout << "Hello, World" << endl << endl; cout << "Where does this line end up?"; //Prints out: //Hello, World // //Where does this line end up? Whereas cout << "Hello, World" << endl; cout << "Where does this line end up?"; //Prints out: //Hello, World //Where does this line end up? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:163
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-08T15:34:42Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:160
Subject:endl means "end line" and is similar to hitting the 'enter' key on the keyboard. Having two 'endl' statements will insert two new lines after "Hello, World" versus having one 'endl' will only have one new line after "Hello, World" (which will be the line immediately below "Hello, World".
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:164
Poster:student
Num Views:61
Type:question
Created:2014-09-08T15:41:11Z
Tags:lecture
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:cout vs cin
Content:Why can't we just type "hello, mary lou" using cout instead of using cin and getline?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:165
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-08T15:42:51Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:164
Subject:
Content:We use cin and getline when we want the user to type their own name in. You can just use cout, but it will not take into account the user input (i.e. everyone in the world will be Mary Lou).
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:166
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-08T15:43:14Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:164
Subject:
Content:We want to have one piece of code that is a little more flexible. If you just write: cout << "Hello, Mary Lou" << endl; Then the program will only ever be able to greet Mary Lou. Using cin and getline for input, we can have one piece of code that greets anyone, rather than writing separate code for each person you want to greet. More generally, remember the following rule: cout - used for outputting stuff to screen - use insertion operator << cin - used for accepting input from screen - use extraction operator >>
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:167
Poster:student

Response To:-1
Subject:Even one the screen it seems to have 7 lines, but I think the last /n will make a new blank line. Why don't we think it as print 8 lines?
Content:This is the question: How many lines are printed out by this statement: cout << "abc\ndef\tghi\njkl" << endl << endl << "mno\n\npqr\n"; I think the first line is abc\ndef\tghi\njkl second line is blank and the third line is mno\n\npqr\n So it should be 3. But the answer is not 0,1,2,3,4,5,or 6. I am really confused.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:187
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-08T23:55:53Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:186
Subject:
Content:have you put this into either xcode to visual and tried it out? remember cout << "\n" is the same thing as cout << endl; EDIT: cout << endl; and cout <<"\n" BEHAVE the same in general in terms of what we're doing with them right now. If you're planning on going to EECS 280 or pursuing programming further, file it away somewhere in your brain for later that using cout << endl; does some extra work that the other method does not, which is called "buffer flushing". Again, this won't matter until later.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:188
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-08T23:56:43Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:186
Subject:
Content:Remember that each \n also indicates a new line. So add up all "\n"'s and "endl"'s to get the total number of lines printed by the statement. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:211
Poster:student
Num Views:66
Type:question
Created:2014-09-09T01:47:09Z
Tags:codelab
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:float
Content:Could you explain float, double? why we cannot dived to int variable directly? what does float( int/int) do?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:212
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-09T01:50:53Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:211
Subject:
Content:These are the exact topics of Wed's lecture What happens is in C++ it trys to maintain the same datatype. int / int will be an int double / double will be a double But on the int / int if you would like to maintain the decimal values, then you need to turn at least one of them to a double double x = 3; double y = 4; cout << (double) x / y; As for what float(int / int) will do: Operations behave as math does in C++: 1. Innermost expression will be evaluated first, so float(1/2) turns into float(0) -- 1/2 integer division == 0 2. Then float() is applied to the result: float(0) == 0.0
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:213
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-09T02:06:59Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:211
Subject:
Content:C++ (and many other high-level languages) try to maintain the datatype that preserves higher accuracy. For example: x = (10/4) This will yield 2, since the accuracy is limited to integers, thus it results in an integer. However, if either or both of the values used is a float/double: x = (10.0/4) The answer will yield 2.5, since the 10.0 has a higher degree of accuracy than 4. Think back to significant figures in whatever high school science class you may have taken. It's somewhat related, only imagine floats/doubles having a very long trail of significant figures that is usually not shown. In essence, using a float 1.0 is using 1.000000 (seven sigfigs), and using a double 1.0 is using 1.000000000000000 (16 sigfigs). Definitely much higher accuracy compared to 10. :P I won't get into floating point addition errors and that stuff, since I don't quite understand completely myself as of yet.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:214
Poster:student
Num Views:19
Type:question
Created:2014-09-09T01:53:00Z

Response To:-1
Subject:Project 1 Batches
Content:Hello, Are we to assume that one person will purchase a batch of cupcakes? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:218
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-09T02:17:18Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:217
Subject:
Content:Do you mean that if the input response to "How many people do you need to serve?" is "1" then the output will read "You need to make: 1 batch of cupcakes"? If so, yes, because although the serving size is 1 cupcake/person (1/12 of a batch), you cannot have a partial batch of cupcakes. From what I understand, you'll just round to the nearest whole number of batches, so if you're serving 14 people, that's 14 cupcakes, so 2 batches. At least, that's my understanding. (So even if the person isn't purchasing a full batch of cupcakes, you still have to make the full batch.)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:226
Poster:student
Num Views:44
Type:question
Created:2014-09-09T02:07:44Z
Tags:zyante
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:A Zyante bug maybe
Content:This is under section 1.4 basic input. When I enter 0.5, it appears to record my input as 0 for some reason. After scrutinizing the code, I don't know why this happens. So I figured it would be good to publicize this problem. <image> 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:227
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-09T02:11:33Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:226
Subject:
Content:You are attempting to input a float/double into a variable that is declared as an integer. What C++ is doing is it's flooring (think rounding, but to the lesser integer, not closest) your input, forcing it to be an integer value. If you input 1.5, it will treat it as a 1. 2.9 -> 2. 3.111111 -> 3. So on and so forth.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:237
Poster:instructor
Num Views:54
Type:question
Created:2014-09-09T15:06:38Z
Tags:zyante
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:problem with Zyante 2.16.1
Content:in this exercise the problem is that int isn't large enough to hold the value 10,000 when its cubed. but why then when I change int cubeVolume to long long cubeVolume, the code still does not run correctly? instead I had to change int sideLength to long long sideLength in addition to cubeVolume in order to get it to run. why is this?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:238
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-09T15:29:30Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:237
Subject:
Content:I think this happens due to implicit typecasting. When you're multiplying (sideLength * sideLength * sideLength), it's treated as an integer multiplication, not a long long multiplication. Hence the overflow. Think about it this way - just like mathematics and algebra, operations happen from the inside out: 1. long long x = (int1 * int2 * int3) 2. long long x = (int1times2 * int3) // multiplication goes left to right, one at a time 3. long long x = (int1times2times3) // this is still an int, so we're overflowing now 4. long long x gets assigned the result // but we've already overflowed, so long long is useless here One way to avoid this will be to first assign sideLength to cubeVolume, and then multiply cubeVolume with itself three times.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:239
Poster:student
Num Views:16
Type:question
Created:2014-09-09T15:09:24Z
Tags:other
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Office Hours
Content:I'm on the office hours link and it says we have to submit a request topic. What exactly does that mean? Are we requesting a topic to be discussed or are we requesting to sign up for office hours? Is there a way we can just see a schedule of all the office hours and just show up?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:240
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-09T15:19:02Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:239
Subject:
Content:The page you were on is just an online office hours signup sheet. When you signup for office hours, you have to request a specific topic for help (eg. "P1 compiler error", or "variable declaration"). However, office hours will always be held at the times specified on the calendar. To see office hours, go to calendar, click on the small arrow on the top right corner (beside "Week", "Month", "Agenda"), and uncheck all check boxes except "183oh". 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:241

Subject:Potential Zyante Bug (Section 2.12, Activity 12)
Content:The second question in the topic of binary numbers is as follows: "Convert the binary number 010001000 to a decimal number." I inputted those two 1's at the binary compiler above the question and got 72 (assuming the binary numbers go from 1-128 from right-to-left), but it said it was incorrect, and in its explanation, it put: "Each 1 bit has a weight, so the answer is 0+128+_+_+_+_+_+_+_" Shouldn't the 128 be at the far left?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:249
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-09T22:32:58Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:248
Subject:
Content:Note that the binary number "010001000" has 9 bits. However, the binary-to-decimal converter above can only accept 8 bits. So you need to discard the leading zero before giving the binary number to the converter.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:266
Poster:student
Num Views:77
Type:question
Created:2014-09-09T23:56:07Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Just wanted to insert a comment on how funny the "stylistic catastrophe" example is. What is the context of this code? Or is it just a sample code used to illustrate terrible coding practice?
Content:The style guide suggests no more than 80 characters per line ... does this include comments?? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:267
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-10T00:03:37Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:266
Subject:
Content:Yes, comments should fit within 80 characters. EDIT: We are extending this to 90 characters for the projects. This still includes comments. Mostly, we're just interested in avoiding stylistic catastrophes such as this: stringstream whatIsThis; whatIsThis<<p; int $; string soComplex; whatIsThis>>soComplex; int onbegrijpelijkharibo = 0; int $$$ = 2;int ___ = static_cast<int>(soComplex.length()) + whatIsThis.good(); ofstream xyz(OUTPUT_FILE_NAME); for(unsigned int x = xyz.good(); x < ___; x++){whatIsThis >> soComplex;$$$ += 1;}for (unsigned int __=0; $$$ *= 8, $ = 71, __<___; onbegrijpelijkharibo += 1){for(;___>__;--___){whatIsThis >> soComplex; onbegrijpelijkharibo = 10 * isdigit(soComplex[soComplex.length() - 2*whatIsThis.good()]); onbegrijpelijkharibo += soComplex[soComplex.length() - whatIsThis.good()] - $$$; xyz << static_cast<char>(onbegrijpelijkharibo * ___ + $) << '|';}}xyz.close(); 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:286
Poster:student
Num Views:37
Type:question
Created:2014-09-10T01:14:06Z
Tags:zyante
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Question with Zyante 2.7 (initializing char?)
Content:Zyante 2.7 is about Characters. Quick question, should we initialize char when programming and why? Will char be empty if not initialized, like string does?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:287
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-10T01:30:45Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:286
Subject:
Content:From experimenting with activity 2.7.2, it seems that yes, char will be empty if not initialized? I modified the program so that there was no initialization for char sepSym, and when in printed, there were no errors, but the characters had no value. (I don't know for sure, though.)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:288
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-10T13:44:36Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:286
Subject:
Content:Every character is represented by an ASCII value that is an integer that represents that character. For example 'A' is 65 and 'B' is 66. Every primitive data type in C++ initializes to 0. 0 is a reserved character in ASCII that stands for null or empty. So if it makes sense in your program for the character to be empty then you do not need to initialize your char value.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Response To:-1
Subject:Running project in Visual Studio
Content:Hi, I wrote a program in Visual Studio that asks the user to input a players name, passing yards, receiving yards, and rushing yards. then it takes the user input and runs calculations on those stats to turn them into point values. My final line of code is - player name is worth # points. my code runs all the way through without issues but the input window closes before I can read the value my calculation outputs. Is there a way to keep that window open or to stop it from automatically closing?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:297
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-10T02:32:53Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:296
Subject:
Content:See <link> Running the Program section in Getting Started with Visual Studio Guide. What you're going to want to do is set a "breakpoint." We will be discussing these shortly so don't worry if it sounds odd. To do this, click on the grey column right next to the line to the left of your code. You will see a little red dot. You need to set this red dot on the last line of your main program (return 0). This will stop the program from completely executing and exiting.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:303
Poster:student
Num Views:42
Type:question
Created:2014-09-10T04:17:05Z
Tags:other
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Multiple getline(cin, var) - only the first asks for input
Content:I have a code that asks for player 1's name = getline(cin, playerName); some other lines of code asking for stat inputs and then another getline for player 2 = getline(cin, playerName2); when I run the code, everything works except for the 2nd getline, it skips it and moves on to the next cin statement. Why is this or what should I do?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:304
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-10T04:23:03Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:303
Subject:
Content:I'm going to guess that whatever you have in between your first and last getline statements contains calls to cin's >> operator. When you call cin's >> operator, it 1. Ignores all leading whitespace 2. Reads until it hits another whitespace 3. Stops, leaving whatever whitespace it has found in the read buffer. However, when you call getline, it 1. Reads until it finds a newline (unless you've specified otherwise) 2. Consumes that newline from the buffer Therefore, when you call the >> operator in mid-program, it's leaving the newline from your input in the buffer. Then when getline comes around again at the end of the program, it's finding that the buffer contains a newline, then whatever you meant for it to read, and it's grabbing just the newline. Generally, either use getline or >> - mixing and matching tends to cause problems like this.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:305
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-10T04:25:49Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:303
Subject:Alright thanks. So would you recommend just always using getline instead of cin if we have to use a getline in our code?
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:306
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-10T04:27:53Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:303
Subject:Generally, if you only have to read strings, getline is great. Otherwise use >>
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:307
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-10T04:29:59Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:303
Subject:will I lose style points or is it a bad habbit to use getline all the time or over cin?
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:308
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-10T17:24:39Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:303
Subject:The use of getline vs >> is entirely dependent on what the program is supposed to do. If you only need one word at a time and have no care about the white spaces, then >> will always be your choice of input because it skips all leading white spaces and stops at the next whitespace. If you do care about white spaces, getline is your method of choice because you actually want those white spaces. TL;DR: It's nota choice of style, it's a choice of function. So no, you won't lose style points.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:() vs (void)
Content:is int main () the same as int main (void)?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:321
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-10T15:25:52Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:320
Subject:
Content:Yes. "Void" basically means "nothing".
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:322
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-10T15:43:46Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:320
Subject:
Content:int main() int main(void)int main(int argc, char* argv[])main() main(void)main(int argc, char* argv[]) In c++11, these are all valid ways to declare your main function. Better style to include "int" but coders are lazy so we made it implicit in new versions of c++.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:325
Poster:student
Num Views:58
Type:question
Created:2014-09-10T15:31:39Z
Tags:lecture
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:What does return 0 actually mean?
Content:The way it's explained makes it seem like return 0 is something you put at the end of your code to make it error-free which makes absolutely no sense.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:326
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-10T15:36:43Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:325
Subject:
Content:basically what "return 0;" does is give a value that should return if everything is working correctly. so if you run your program and see the value that returns (I believe in VisualStudio this will be in the output with something like "the program [program name] has exited with code 0", I'm not sure how it works in XCode), and it isn't 0, you know for a fact you have a problem you need to fix.--Good answer :) add something in about the operating system and why it cares about return codes and it'll be perfect!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:327
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-10T15:38:40Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:325
Subject:
Content:Your program is run by the operating system. When your program returns, it provides information back to the operating system regarding how things went. Conventionally, returning 0 means nothing went wrong. So if you have a program that might break beyond all possible repair, you'd have it consider returning 1, -1 or something else non-zero, meaning "something went wrong and the program couldn't handle it." For example: int main () { if (programBroken()) { return 1; } else { // all good! return 0; }}
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:328
Poster:student
Num Views:11
Type:question
Created:2014-09-10T15:55:11Z
Tags:lecture
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:When to use int vs double?
Content:Title
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:329
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-10T15:58:50Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:328
Subject:
Content:you're going to want to use int when your number is an integer value, so for example, the amount of siblings you have, or the amount of classes you had yesterday. those two can only be whole numbers, not fractions/decimals, so you would use int. now, if you were going to record something like an average, or a measurement that's accurate to one or more decimal places (like if something weighs 2.5 grams), then you would use a double.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:337

Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-10T17:01:12Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:334
Subject:
Content:-- As stated in <link> @6, please include the question itself in your post when asking for help on CodeLab questions. -- It sounds like an issue where you have a string literal (a string that is wrapped in quotation marks) that is following some kind of expression. For example, I created this same error with the following code int a = 1; cout << a " and now I have a string"; // should be // cout << a << " and now I have a string"; Make sure that your values and variable are separated by the appropriate operators and that you have semicolons in the right places.

Piazza Post:341

Created:2014-09-10T18:36:01Z

Response To:340

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:342
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-10T21:21:10Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:340
Subject:
Content:By spaces they do not mean how many characters are being printed. They mean - among the characters being printed, how many are literally the space character (i.e., how many characters are literally ' ').

Piazza Post:352
Poster:student
Num Views:6
Type:question
Created:2014-09-10T21:19:14Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Style Grader Pluralize
Content:What does it mean when it says that "pluralize is missing a complete RME? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:353
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-10T21:28:30Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:352
Subject:
Content:You need not worry about this for Project 1. RME stands for Requires, Modifies, and Effects. For each function other than the main function we want you to have a comment before the method that tells us what the method requires, what the method modifies, and what the method effects. You can find an example here as well as a complete list of what the style grader is checking.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:355
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-10T21:44:49Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:354
Subject:
Content:Using escape sequences is a good way to get characters such as backslash and quotations into a string. Try looking them up, I think we may have reviewed them in class before or on the Zyante readings.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:356
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-10T22:10:37Z
Tags:
Endorsements:4
Response To:354
Subject:
Content:When you have double quotes within strings, use an escape sequence: cout << "Hello, world!" << endl; would print: Hello, world! whereas: cout << "Hello, \"world\"!" << endl; would print: Hello, "world"! Note the escaped double quotes around "world". <link> Here is a list of escape sequences.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:363
Poster:student
Num Views:10

Created:2014-09-10T23:16:23Z
Tags:other
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Microsoft Visual Studio 2013 Debugging
Content:I have tried debugging the " Hello World " example on Visual Studio 2013 and followed exactly what was done in the "Getting started with Visual Studio" guide (including setting the breakpoint.) but the output still closes within a split second somehow. Any idea why? Thanks for helping :) I've tried doing the break point at the end of my main function but it still doesn't work.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:364
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-10T23:58:52Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:363
Subject:
Content:The short answer is that your program is completing without issue and so the debugging window is disappearing. To prevent this, you can place what's called a break point at the end of your main function by clicking in the margin to the left of your return statement. I would recommend stopping by office hours and getting a GSI or IA to show you, or asking your discussion leader, if you'd like a demonstration.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:370
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-10T23:57:03Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:369
Subject:
Content:this is explained in the "Getting Started with xCode" and "Getting Started with Visual" documents posted on our website -- under LINKS on the home page of umich.edu/~eecs183 Within the docs: look under "Tuning xCode" or "Tuning Visual" or Visual Studio: <link> http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa265105%28v=vs.60%29.aspx; also see <link> http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14167033/visual-studio-2010-replace-tab-with-4-spaces XCode: <link> http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16208065/xcode-indentation-alignment-settings-spaces-tabs (look into the first answer) 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:371
Poster:student
Num Views:14
Type:question
Created:2014-09-11T00:07:55Z
Tags:zyante
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:what is default setting?
Content:This is a sentence quoted from Zyante section 1.6: "Default settings commonly do NOT report all important issues. Good practice is to explicitly configure the compiler to report most warnings." But what is default setting and how to configure the compiler to report most warnings? Thanks for solving this question!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:372
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-11T00:21:18Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:371
Subject:
Content:The default setting is the setting that you get when you create a new project (say in Visual Studio or XCode). You can change the default setting to generate all compiler warnings as follows: Visual Studio: <link> http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/thxezb7y.aspx; also see <link> http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/23k5d385.aspx XCode: <link> http://blog.manbolo.com/2012/08/17/warnings-in-xcode For Visual Studio, the "/Wall" option enables all warnings. For XCode, there is the "-Wall" option, and there is also the more advanced option "-Weverything" that prints even more stuff. Note: Wall = Warn All
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:373
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-11T00:37:11Z

Piazza Post:377
Poster:student
Num Views:13
Type:question
Created:2014-09-11T00:33:38Z
Tags:other
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:question when input a variable
Content:when we want to input a variable (a number, for example), can we simply type: int number; or do we need to set an initial value of the variable, like this: int number = o; what's the difference between these two? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:378
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-11T00:39:57Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:377
Subject:
Content:when you create a variable, you have to declare the variable and then initialize it in order to be able to use it, but you can do the two things in two different statements. the first instance you have is an example of just declaring, while the second does both in one statement. now, you will have to initialize eventually (that's how you get a value into a variable). however, with integers (and doubles, for that matter), if you don't ever initialize it, the value is automatically set at 0. so if you want the value to be zero, I guess you could just leave it as int number; without ever saying int number = 0; 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:379
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-11T00:41:03Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:377
Subject:
Content:You can either input a variable from keyboard: int number; cin >> number; // Please make sure to include a cout statement before cin that prompts the user to enter something. Or you can initialize the variable to an initial value: int number; number = 0; More compactly: int number = 0; The two use cases are different. For the first one, you want the user to input a number. For the second one, the programmer is initializing a number, possibly for latter computations. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:380
Poster:student
Num Views:7
Type:question
Created:2014-09-11T01:27:56Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:What does lldb mean?
Content:When I am trying to run the program in XCode, lldb always shows up randomly and outputs after that are all cut off. What does that mean and how should I fix it?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:381
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-11T01:37:50Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:380
Subject:
Content:lldb is Apple's debugger in Xcode. If your program stops executing on it's own, it's probably because something went wrong and you have a run-time error. An example of this would be diving by 0, but there could also be lots of other things. Might be helpful: <link> http://stackoverflow.com/questions/16999127/lldb-run-time-error-on-xcode <link> https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/documentation/IDEs/Conceptual/gdb_to_lldb_transition_guide/document/Introduction.html 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:414
Poster:student
Num Views:118
Type:question
Created:2014-09-11T15:30:21Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Plurals Function
Content:Hello, the project outline says that there is a plural function but how do i actually use that? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:415
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-11T15:41:53Z
Tags:
Endorsements:3
Response To:414
Subject:
Content:In your output, you'll use the pluralize function to indicate whether an item is singular, or plural. For example: cout << "I have " << 1 << " " << pluralize("bag", "bags", 1) << " of peanuts." << endl; will output: "I have 1 bag of peanuts." Whereas: cout << "I have " << 3 << " " << pluralize("bag", "bags", 3) << " of peanuts." << endl; will output: "I have 3 bags of peanuts." 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:416
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-11T18:00:53Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0

Subject:What if the number of the bags I want to output is undetermined. It could be 1 or 2 or 6? How can I use the plural function?

Piazza Post:417
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-11T18:07:32Z

Endorsements:0
Response To:414
Subject:You should try to set up a variable that contains the number of bags. That way when you pass that variable into the pluralize() function, the function will behave appropriately with whatever value is contained in the variable.

Piazza Post:426
Poster:student
Num Views:38
Type:question
Created:2014-09-11T16:40:10Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Figuring out the number of batches
Content:If you are trying to make the program calculate how many batches one would need depending on the amount of people, you would have to use an algorithm right? If not, what would be the best way to approach this situation? Thank you in advance.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:427
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-11T17:22:15Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:426
Subject:
Content:You can assume each person will only eat 1 cupcake (even if that's unrealistic because who eats just one cupcake?). This means if there are 12 people you need 1 batch and for 13 people you need 2 batches. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:428
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-11T17:23:43Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:426
Subject:Thank you for your answer. What would be the best way to make the program output two batches for 13 or more cupcakes?
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:429
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-11T17:36:19Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:426
Subject:There are numerous algorithms for doing this. One of the easiest methods is using a function call ceil() which is in the cmath library (already provided in the file). I suggest going to Google and searching for this function, you'll find plenty of resources about what it does and how you can use it. If you need more help feel free to post a follow up :)
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:433
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-11T18:31:16Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:426
Subject:Sure! (In case anyone still needs to know what ceil is, you can look it up <link> here). So ceil is a function that takes a double parameter and returns a double (technically you could say it returns an int because it returns a whole number/integer value). So if we had the following code: double myVar = 2.3, myVar2 = 3.0, myVar3 = 11.01; cout << ceil(myVar) << " " << ceil(myVar2) << " " << ceil(myVar3) << endl; The final output of this program would be: 3.0 3.0 12.0 In other words, the way you use the function is you provide the function the double value you want to perform a ceiling on (either a variable or math expression) and then you do something with the value the function returns (for example, I printed it, but you could also save it into a variable).
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:434
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-11T19:46:24Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:426
Subject:I thought a ceiling rounded up, so 2.3 would go to 3? Also how do you determine what you want your ceiling to round up to in terms of having to have to buy the whole of an ingredient, like a whole bag of flour even if you only want a little bit of the next bag.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:449
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-11T18:15:14Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:447
Subject:
Content:There is a lot of math involved, and figuring out that math is a part of the project. After receiving the number of people that need to be served, first calculate the number of batches needed to serve that many people. The ingredients list is then worked out based on the number of batches you need, using the recipe given as a guide. All the rest is math that you'll have to have the code do for you. There is only once input. The rest is all math and code.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Mike is slowly working on refining the style grader

Piazza Post:493
Poster:student
Num Views:18
Type:question
Created:2014-09-12T01:51:05Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:style grader
Content:When i submitted my .cpp file to the style grader, it mentioned "pluralize is missing a complete RME", what exactly does it mean? Thank you!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:494
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-12T02:01:08Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:493
Subject:
Content:RMEs are descriptions of what the function does. It stands for "Requires, Modifies, Effects". For example, here is an RME for a function calcAverageASCII: //Requires: n != 0, length of strAvg == n //Modifies: nothing //Effects: calculates and returns the average ascii value of the characters in a string char calcAverageASCII(string strAvg, int n); You're more than welcome to write your own for pluralize, but since it is instructor-provided code, you will not be penalized on style grading if you do not include one.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:495
Poster:student
Num Views:3
Type:question
Created:2014-09-12T02:05:33Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1

Content:how do i put quotation marks around best ever? Thanks.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Poster:instructor

Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-12T02:09:02Z

Endorsements:0

Subject:

Piazza Post:497
Poster:student

Created:2014-09-12T02:14:54Z

Subject:File saving

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:498
Poster:instructor

Piazza Post:509
Poster:student
Num Views:35
Type:question
Created:2014-09-12T03:06:33Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Some confusion about batch calculation
Content:I know this has been discussed a bit already, but I'm still pretty confused about how to set up the calculation for how many batches are needed depending on what input the user puts in. Any ideas?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:510
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-12T03:17:38Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:509
Subject:
Content:You know that there are 12 cupcakes in a batch, and your program will ask for how many people are eating. We are assuming each person will only eat 1 cupcake. This means that the number of cupcakes you need is equal to the number of people eating. Then you have to calculate how many batches of cupcakes you will need to make in order to make that number of cupcakes.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:511
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-12T03:31:38Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:509
Subject:
Content:I'll list a few key input values and resulting batch quantities to help illustrate how many you're supposed to be having per person. 0 people, 0 batches. 1 person, 1 batch. 12 people, 1 batch. 13 people, 2 batches. 24 people, 2 batches. 25 people, 3 batches. This should be enough for you to figure out the pattern and create an algorithm to replicate its behavior. The way the problem was worded makes the pattern a lot harder to recognize than if it were presented like above, so hopefully this helps.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:512
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-12T03:32:56Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:509
Subject:To instructors: To aid OP, I've listed only a few input and corresponding output values without disclosing the math or code to work it out. Is this permissible, as I am not explicitly revealing a possible answer (math, algorithm, or code)?
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:513
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-12T03:48:52Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:509
Subject:Yes, this is permissible for this project. I'm fact, some of these are directly provided in the spec as test cases. However, future projects will have test suites which require you to submit code/files for testing purposes and those are checked through the auto grader. So in the future it is best to describe what sort of things to test for, instead of specific tests.
Content:None

Piazza Post:518
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-12T03:41:38Z

Endorsements:2
Response To:516
Subject:
Content:Yes, system("pause"); will make you fail the autograder. You need to set a breakpoint. See https://www.umich.edu/~eecs183/docs/getting_started_with_visual_studio.html#_running_the_program.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:536
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-12T11:46:09Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:534
Subject:
Content:The reason is that some word processors insert secret hidden characters that we can't see but the compiler does see and that was breaking it. If you want to do this in the future though, Id suggest using a plain text editor and saving the contents into a .txt file instead

Piazza Post:541
Poster:student
Num Views:48
Type:question
Created:2014-09-12T12:36:59Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Style Grader
Content:If our programs are graded on functionality, does the style matter? for instance I received an error which stated I have over 80 characters on one line, I can easily change that, however I prefer to keep each line in one cout function (one cout function per line).
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:542
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-12T13:29:58Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:541
Subject:
Content:Our programs will be graded on both style and functionality. If you have an exceedingly long line, it makes the program less readable, which might be a pain for someone who would have to maintain your code later, or it may even make it harder for you to understand what you were trying to do in that line if you ever went back and looked at your code. Since this is an intro course, they are trying to teach good habits while we're new. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:543
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-12T14:16:59Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:541
Subject:
Content:One way you can accomplish the task of having one cout statement is to break the statement up over multiple lines. For example changing cout << "this is line 1" << endl << "this is line 2" << endl; You could do cout << "this is line 1" << endl << "this is line 2" << endl;
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:544
Poster:student

Type:followup

Piazza Post:554

Piazza Post:575
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-12T20:26:14Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:574
Subject:
Content:For making strings plural, yes you will be marked down because it will be repeated code (since you already a function that will do it). As for the math, you can do it that way but I STRONGLY recommend using the ceil function. If you search piazza you'll find some posts about it and how to use it.

Subject:Indentations when adding expressions

Because this one assignment statement is very long, I need to use multiple lines. Subject:CodeLab 11008 (new one)
Content:I can't figure out why my answer for this is not working: int k; double d; string s; cin >> k; cin >> d; cin >> s; cout << s << " " << d << " " << k; endl; cout << k << " " << d << " " << s;
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:589
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-12T22:04:52Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:588
Subject:
Content:So, in C++ whenever you want to print something out with multiple breaks in between, say variables or different string literals, you must use the put-to operator (<<). This includes any kind of line break you include. Look for something in your code that doesn't follow that rule.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:590
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-12T22:35:35Z

Endorsements:0
Response To:588
Subject:Try putting an endl; in your second line

Piazza Post:591
Poster:instructor
Num Views:35
Type:question
Created:2014-09-12T22:01:25Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:For the outdated prompt, it is telling you that you have made changes to the source code since the last time the code was compiled. You may check the box in this prompt to not show it again. When you are confronted with the build errors, I believe you want to select No. Otherwise it may be attempting to execute the last successfully compile executable. If you have not yet successfully compiled the program yet, then this file will not be found. When you get the build error prompt, select No and you should then see the list of errors in the bottom window (labeled Error List in Visual Studio) of your IDE.
Content:I added the source file cupcakes.cpp to my project, but then nothing happened. I can only edit the program by editing the source itself, which I know I'm not supposed to do because it doesn't build properly. How can I work on the solution without doing anything to the cupcakes.cpp source?

Piazza Post:601
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-13T00:14:07Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:600
Subject:
Content:I would go from number of batches and figure out how much butter that would take If you have 1 batch, that would take 1.5 cups or 12 oz -- that's 1 lb 2 batch would take 2 * 12 or 24 oz -- that's 2 lbs needed etc
