Piazza Post:623
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-13T18:55:02Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:616
Subject:The answer is: If you have this issue, that means in a previous problem you did a copy/paste from some editor that was NOT a text editor -- perhaps word or textedit or some other rich text editor and it has all sorts of control characters as part of it. This messes with your account such that the next time you try and login it cannot load the work you have already done. I have contacted the head of CodeLab and he is going through all of your work and deleted each exercise that was not totally TEXT. Solution, use a text editor for all your work or this will happen again. And next time, you are on your own to get it resolved.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:624
Poster:student
Num Views:81
Type:question
Created:2014-09-13T06:48:28Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Plural on Eggs
Content:I failed the autograder test #9 "Plural on Eggs". I did not use the provided pluralize function as there was no need. My statement is something like: cout << numEggs << " dozen eggs" << endl; The output does not change: 1 dozen eggs 6 dozen eggs Is the autograder telling me to use the pluralize function even though it isn't needed or am I overlooking something?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:625
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-13T13:04:35Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:624
Subject:
Content:It's a test to make sure you have the correct form for a plural of "dozen eggs" which is "dozen eggs" as you said. This means your math is probably off for some ingredient in that test Also remember that the test may say "Plural on Eggs" but there is a lot that gets printed. If you calculated the final cost incorrectly, you would also fail this test. So yes it will check for most likely "2 dozen eggs" but everything else needs to be correct also.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:626
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-13T20:02:27Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:624
Subject:It ended up being an error caused by when I chose to round up during the calculations. I passed all the test cases after I fixed it. Thanks.
Content:None

Piazza Post:629
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-13T14:22:07Z
Tags:
Endorsements:4
Response To:628
Subject:
Content:use the escape character \ right before each quotation mark! so for example, if you wanted to print "Hello, World!" with the quotation marks, you would do cout << "\"Hello, World!\"";

Subject:Style Grader : function definition location
Content:Style grader says "pluralize is implemented above main. Keep function definitions below main or in a separate .cpp file." but Xcode won't allow me to move the function definition below main () {. How should I approach this? Thanks!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:646
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-13T17:09:03Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:645
Subject:
Content:You should be able to place the definition of pluralize below main, just make sure it is outside of the braces. it should look like #include <iostream> #include ... string pluralize(string single, string plural, int number); int main() { // ... all your code return 0; } string pluralize(string single, string plural, int number) { // .... } 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:649
Poster:instructor
Num Views:0
Type:note
Created:2014-09-13T19:21:16Z
Tags:codelab
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Regarding Codelab
Content:Caution: if you write code in some type of word processor before you copy/paste to CodeLab to submit the code, make sure the editor you are using is a straight TEXT editor and not a rich text editor (RTF). Word is a rich text editor as is text edit and is text wrangler. The editor with xcode and visual are TEXT only editors so they are safe. The issue with rich text editors is they store many formatting characters. When you copy/paste from RTF editors into CodeLab, the formatting goes along with it. An this causes an issue. The next time you try and log into CodeLab, your exercises will never load -- you will wait forever. This will take you contacting TuringsCraft and asking them to go through all your submits and delete the ones where you copy/pasted from an RTF editor instead of a TEXT only editor. This will take awhile for them to complete. Bottom line: if you want to copy/paste code, make absolutely positive you are doing it from a text only editor or you will lock yourself out of your account.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:650
Poster:student
Num Views:52
Type:question
Created:2014-09-13T19:22:39Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:autograde terminology
Content:1 What does "exact on sugar" mean? Get rid of ceil, but I need ceil in order for it to work. 2 What does "one over on sugar" mean? 3 It keeps saying "plural on flour" but my pluralize function looks good to me? 4 And what does "40 batches" mean as test 14? Thank you very much.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:651
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-13T19:45:35Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:650
Subject:
Content:"exact on sugar" means that you have just enough sugar to make how many batches you need. You will use all the sugar you bought "one over on sugar" means you are just a little short and need one more bag "plural on flour" means do you have 2 bags of flour remember many other things are also output. If you miss this one, it may be because you missed the total cost, or some other item "40 batches" means you will be making 40 batches
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:652
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-14T04:34:43Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:650
Subject:
Content:1) "Is the quantity of sugar correct?" 2) "Whoops, you have one more than you needed on sugar." 3) "Is the outputted word the correct form, singular or plural, based on the quantity?" 4) "There should be 40 batches..."

Subject:Write code within the curly braces that are closest to main. See below. string pluralize(string single, string plural, int number); int main() { // Write code here return 0; } string pluralize(string single, string plural, int number) { if (number == 1) { return single; } return plural; }

Content:a const always needs to be initialized const int INCHES_PER_FEET = 12;

Response To:688
Subject:I'm glad you solved the problem. Also a "const" is really not a "variable" The definition of the 'variable' is the value within that identifier can 'vary' during the execution of the program. The value of a const never changes. Therefore technically not a variable

Subject:For people having trouble finding the button, this is what you're looking for: <image> All the way in the top right corner of xcode, you'll see these three buttons. You should then see this pop up in the bottom half of xcode:<image>

Piazza Post:735
Poster:student
Num Views:65
Type:question
Created:2014-09-14T01:50:10Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:What does "what does the method modify" exactly? How can we conclude that whether any value is modifies or not? 
Content:What is the possible R of the pluralize function in the comment? Ezra Chung: Whoops, didn't know I was editing the question!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:736
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-14T01:57:22Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:735
Subject:
Content:It's asking for a description of how the method works in three parts, as instructed @157: - What does the method require? - What does the method modify? - What is the effect of using the method? (i.o.w. what does it do?) Here's an example of an RME I wrote for the pluralize method, since the style error was annoying me: /** string pluralize(string single, string plural, int number){...} *** Requires: singular noun, plural noun, quantity. *** Modifies: nothing. *** Effects: returns singular or plural form when appropriate. **/ string pluralize(string single, string plural, int number){...} Instructors: Since this is a comment thing, and the actual code is instructor-provided, it's alright to share this example, right?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:737
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-14T01:58:14Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:735
Subject:
Content:The Requires would be: Parameters: single - Single form of the word plural - Plural form of the word number - how many there are; number will be >= 1
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:749
Poster:student
Num Views:20
Type:question
Created:2014-09-14T03:19:01Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Brackets issue with the style grader
Content:I submitted my code to the style grader and the only thing it outputted was "Your braces should be either Egyptian or block style, pick one" and it's referring specifically to the pluralize function (which I copied directly from the given code on the prompt). As far as I see, only curly brackets are used in that section, so I'm not really sure what to do about this.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:750
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-14T03:29:03Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:749
Subject:
Content:Make sure your brace style in main matches the style in pluralize. The code is provided, but sometimes your IDE will automatically format the braces into a different style. Check to see if the braces are consistent between main and pluralize. LIke this: int main(){ ... } string pluralize(string single, string plural, int number) { if (number == 1) { return single; } return plural; } or this: int main() { ... } string pluralize(string single, string plural, int number) { if (number == 1) { return single; } return plural; }
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Poster:student

Type:followup

Piazza Post:760
Poster:student
Num Views:24
Type:question
Created:2014-09-14T05:00:45Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Pluralize Function and breakpoints
Content:Hi, I was having trouble with the pluralize function. I downloaded cupcake.cpp and typed just cout << pluralize("bag", "bags", 1); between { and return 0; in the main function. when i debugged it, nothing happened and i'm really confused? this is when i set the breakpoint to after the pluralize function...( so at the very last line of code) i noticed that if i set the breakpoint to where the main function ends, I get "bag" as the output, which seems correct. So I guess I'm wondering, did I do something wrong? Am I using pluralize wrong? Or am I not understanding breakpoints? I was under the impression that break points should be at the very end of code for some reason. but in all honesty, i don't really know what they are 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:761
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-14T05:10:06Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:760
Subject:
Content:What you have there is, in human speech, cout << pluralize("bag", "bags", 1); print on screen the following: {"bag" if value is 1, "bags" if value is not 1, value is 1}; So when you debugged it, nothing happened except printing bag on the screen because that's what the code says to do! In that sense, nothing's wrong with the code and you're using pluralize "correctly".
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:762
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-14T05:19:38Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:760
Subject:right, i get that, but the question i'm asking has more to do with breakpoints. if i set my breakpoint at the last line of code, there is literally nothing on the screen but the blinking light. when i set the breakpoint at earlier in the code, the pluralize function works fine and i get "bag" as predicted. i'm wondering why that is. i'm using visual studio btw

Piazza Post:763
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-14T05:24:02Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:760
Subject:I'm not using Visual Studio, but my hypothesis based on your explanation is that the breakpoint pauses the program AFTER running the line you've chosen, not BEFORE the line. Illustration of what I mean: cout << "line 1" << endl; cout << "line 2" << endl; // <- This line is where you set the breakpoint. cout << "line 3" << endl; I think that will print: line 1 line 2 Therefore, when you put the breakpoint on the return 0; line, it still ran the line, closing the terminal.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:764
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-14T13:19:38Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:760
Subject:actually, in this example if you have 1) cout << "line 1" << endl; 2) cout << "line 2" << endl; // <- breakpoint on this line 3) cout << "line 3" << endl; execution will break when line 2 is reached. The line will NOT execute until you tell it to
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:767
Poster:student
Num Views:31
Type:question
Created:2014-09-14T05:50:29Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Magic Numbers
Content:One of the items on the style guide says that we should define all numbers as ints or doubles, and use the variables (Pi was the given example). Pi is understandable as it is a very large number that could be messed up easily. When making the equations that figure out how many bags/containers of each item we need, are we required to have all the number pre-defined to do well? For example, is this okay: bagsofx = 3.3 / j * 21 ; or should I write: double chickens = 3.3; double store = 21 bagsofx = chickens / j * store; (neither of these formulas are what I used in my code, of course) I only ask because my code uses a lot of numbers that are at most in the tenths place, and it seems like the code would be more difficult to understand if each value had to be written out to be explained.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:768
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-14T06:19:55Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:767
Subject:
Content:Do the latter! The reasoning for this is not because of accuracy, necessarily, but because if you're creating your code to be shared with someone (as you might be in the future), you need it to be readable and understandable. If you use the former, anyone who isn't familiar with the original recipe or instructions will be very confused as to what 3.3 and 21 represent. If you define them with meaningful names, then that element of confusion is eliminated. (Also because if you come back to this code a month in the future, you're not going to remember what numbers in which variables mean what.)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:769
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-14T13:16:21Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:767
Subject:
Content:I suppose you could also do: bagsofx = 3.3 / j * 21 ; // 3.3 is: the number of chickens // j is: I have no idea because it is a really awful variable name // 21 is the number that can be handled at the store but this is even more lengthy, and wordy than the 2nd one in your question When in doubt always always go for readable
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:770

Piazza Post:771
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-14T13:12:58Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:770
Subject:
Content:I assume you mean cout << pluralize("batch", "batches", 1); without the "pluralize" that will be a compile error also with a '1' being passed into pluralize, yes it will always return 'batch' If you want it to reflect 'batch' or 'batches' off the number of batches, then you need to pass that parameter into pluralize cout << pluralize("batch", "batches", numOfBatches);
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:772
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-14T14:52:10Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:770
Subject:
Content:Rather than using 1. Another format is to declare a variable and substitute it into that. Also, your format should be cout << pluralize( "batch" , "batches" , 1). You're forgetting the pluralize function and the qoutation marks.

Piazza Post:782
Poster:student
Num Views:7
Type:question
Created:2014-09-14T15:37:01Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Commenting
Content:I tried using a single line comment right after my code but the character count is over 80. So when i comment above the line of code, does it matter if i use /* */ instead of // for just 1 line of comment even though /* */ is used for multi-line commenting? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:783
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-14T15:41:47Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:782
Subject:
Content:It doesn't matter. You can use /* */ or you can have // on both lines. But if your comment is over 80 characters, it's probably too long and you should consider shortening it. The idea is to help the reader (e.g. TA or you in 6 months) understand what your code does, not to excessively describe every single detail. No need to write in full sentences. See the <link> Style Guide for an example.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:784

Response To:-1
Subject:Unknown Warning
Content:My program runs smoothly but there is this warning sign: Warning 1 warning C4244: 'argument' : conversion from 'double' to 'int', possible loss of data The weird thing is that this only happens when i save then run for the first time. The second time it shows no warning signs. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:788
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-14T17:04:46Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:787
Subject:
Content:I think it's because you are changing data types from double to int (hence dropping anything after the decimal point). If the program is running fine and you just want to get rid of the error, use static casting. i.e. double dValue = 5.0 ; //this assignment will give you that error int iValue = dValue ; //using this assignment instead should fix the error int iValue = static_cast<int> (dValue) ;
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:820

Piazza Post:830
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-14T20:38:21Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:828
Subject:
Content:"Queued for Grading" just means that other people have submitted to the autograder and your program has to wait to be tested. You need to refresh the page until your score shows up (and you get an email from the autograder). But for future reference, if you are copying your text into another file, make sure you save it as plain text.

Piazza Post:835
Poster:student
Num Views:58
Type:question
Created:2014-09-14T20:19:54Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:If statements in Project 1
Content:Are we allowed to use if statements in our Project 1 code? I know we haven't discussed these in class but I'm not sure how else to find the number of batches.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:836
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-14T20:31:44Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:835
Subject:
Content:It is not necessary to use any if statements in your code. Try to figure out a way to calculate the number of batches using mathematical calculations rather than a series of if statements. For example, Rather than going: if (number of people served is greater than x), make n batches, several times, try dividing the number of people by the size of one batch. In general, you will not need to use any if statements in this project if you elect to use the given pluralize function.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:837
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-14T20:45:03Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:835
Subject:But dividing people by one batch would yield either an underestimate (I have to make 2 batches for 13 people, rather than just 1 12-person batch) or a decimal, which is unacceptable since number of batches must be an integer. Im I not sure how to round the batches up if there is a remainder, unless I use an if statement. 
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:838
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-14T20:48:10Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:835
Subject:There is a ceiling function that you can use. It is called ceil(). For example, ceil(2.3) returns 3.
Content:None

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:845
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-14T20:55:41Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:844
Subject:
Content:You have set a breakpoint in your code. The program will stop executing at a line with a breakpoint. Either delete the breakpoint (breakpoints show up to the left of the line of code, as a red dot in Visual Studios or a blue arrow in Xcode) and/or make sure you run without debugging.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-14T21:32:52Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:848
Subject:
Content:The amounts in your shopping list should be integers, because you can only buy whole, say, bags of flour or containers of sour cream. However, your recipe may have some doubles. In fact, I believe many of the ingredients have fractions of cups (or other measurements).

Piazza Post:867
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-15T15:10:36Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:863
Subject:If you need to break one line of code into multiple lines on the screen, then indent all the lines after the first one. This is for good style. For example: total = num1 + num2 + num3 + ... It makes it easier to read, and makes it clear that it is all one equation.

Piazza Post:881
Poster:student
Num Views:10
Type:question
Created:2014-09-15T02:03:28Z
Tags:zyante
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:confusing with the concepts of parameter and argument
Content:can anyone explain what is an argument and parameter and what is the difference ? I am so confusing.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:882
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-15T02:23:15Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:881
Subject:
Content:A parameter is a variable that is part of the function signature and an argument is a value that is passed into the function to satisfy the parameter. For example: int foo(int x, double y) { return x; } int main() { foo(5, 1.3); return 0; } in the above, the parameters are x and y, and the arguments are 5 and 1.3.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:883
Poster:student
Num Views:4
Type:question

Piazza Post:884
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None

Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Pluralize and Xcode
Content:Whenever I put my code through the style checker it says there is a problem because my function for pluralize is before my main, but my program won't work on Xcode unless pluralize is before the main. Should I just keep it before the main even though it says there is something wrong with my style?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:890
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-15T02:45:59Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:889
Subject:
Content:if you use the given code, and place your code in int main(), you should have no issue at all I use xcode and my implementation for pluralize is below main() You need the following line of code before main: string pluralize(string single, string plural, int number); And then the definition of pluralize with curly braces after main.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Response To:-1
Subject:Style grader question-above main?
Content:The autograder gave me 50/50 for runability, but the style grader says: "________ is implemented above main. Keep function definitions below main or in a separate .cpp file" for all my functions. If I copy and paste all my functions so that they are below main, I get the "use of undeclared identifier" message. Is there a way I can resolve this, or is it okay to have my functions implemented above main?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:905
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-15T03:33:42Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:904
Subject:
Content:Declare them above and implement them below: #include <...> using namespace stuff; int myFn(int stuff); int main () { // some other stuff int things; myFn(things); } int myFn(int stuff) { do_the_thing(stuff); // other stuff return stuff + 5; } 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:912
Poster:student
Num Views:10
Type:question
Created:2014-09-15T14:54:30Z
Tags:other
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Visual Studios preferences help
Content:I can't find how to change the preferences in Visual Studios. I want to change it from tabs to spaces and if possible I want to make it so that I can see the line numbers on my code. Does anyone know how to do this?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:913
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-15T15:03:08Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:912
Subject:
Content:For tabs to spaces: -Go to Tools > Options > Text Editor > C/C++ > Tabs -Make sure Tab Size and Indent Size are each 4 -Select "Insert Spaces" rather than "Keep Tabs"
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:914
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-15T15:05:12Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:912
Subject:
Content:At the top ribbon select: Tools -> Options... Then scroll thru the left hand pane and select: Text Editor -> All Languages For tabs, select the Tabs: Text Editor -> All Languages -> Tabs And select the Insert spaces radio button and enter 4 for the tab size. For line numbers: Text Editor -> All Languages ->General and check the box Line Numbers There is also a search feature you will find once you select Tools -> Options. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:920
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-15T17:20:23Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:917
Subject:Those three lines mean that whitespace, substring, and case sensitivity do not matter. So you can add all the whitespace you want and it won't fail the autograder. You can write your program so that everything printed is in all caps and it wouldn't fail the autograder. (Please don't do these things. Just know that you won't fail because of them.)
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:934
Poster:instructor
Num Views:51
Type:note
Created:2014-09-15T17:38:27Z
Tags:logistics, project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Style Grader Concerns
Content:Hi everyone! I wanted to address some concerns about the style grader and its bugs. We coded the style grader because, when we were students, there was no way of knowing anything about our style grade before we turned it in. Currently there are some bugs with the program, but DON'T WORRY! All of your code is graded by humans. You guys are a HUGE help to us by providing us feedback (over 800 projects submitted 2-3 times a day!). We won't use the style grader to grade until it is 100% ready - and even then, human eyes will ALWAYS see your code this semester to ensure proper grading. I wanted to say thanks to everyone for their patience and help - when the style grader is finished and bug free it will help many students for many years, and you guys are playing a big role in preparing it for that! 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:955
Poster:student
Num Views:13
Type:question
Created:2014-09-15T18:22:34Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Style Grader problem with functions
Content:I wrote out my code for cupccakes and when i submitted it to the stylegrader it came back with an error for each one of my functions I used and said that having the functions before main () is incorrect. I thought you could do that and put your functions before the main () sample error: 20 bagsFlour is implemented above main. Keep function definitions below main or in a separate .cpp file
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:956
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-15T18:48:26Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:955
Subject:
Content:It's kind of weird, and I suspect there's something to it that is yet to be explained to us, but the way you declare functions has to be something like this: // Declare functions here. int function1(int x, int y); string function2(string str); // Main function. int main(){ ... } // Actual function definitions here. int function1(int x, int y){ ... } string function2(string str){ ... } Make sure your actual function definitions are below main, and that you're only declaring? initializing? the functions above main.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:965
Poster:student
Num Views:53
Type:question
Created:2014-09-15T20:05:57Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Defining constants before or in main
Content:Does it matter if constants are all defined in a lump before main or should they be defined right before they are used? Is this just a stylistic choice? For instance... Is this better? const double SOME_VALUE = 3.0; const double SOME_VALUE_2 = 2.5; const double SOME_VALUE_3 = 5.0; int main () { cout << SOME_VALUE * SOME_VALUE_2; } or this? int main () { const int SOME_VALUE = 5.0; const int SOME_VALUE_2 = 6.2; cout << SOME_VALUE * SOME_VALUE_2; } 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:966
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-15T21:33:08Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:965
Subject:
Content:It's actually a matter of functionality. The rule is you should create a variable in the smallest scope possible (scope is something we'll be talking about in lecture soon). So the best time to create a global constant would be when you need a variable visible across multiple files, or multiple functions (in other words, a global scope). However, if you only need it in one function (in this case, you only need it in main), declaring them in only that function is more preferable. However, we won't take off points either way in this case, since we would like for you to become accustomed to global constants for future projects. TL;DR: For this project, declaring them in main is preferable, but if you make them global or in main you won't lose style points.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:967
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-16T20:08:03Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:965
Subject:So to clarify, if we put our constants in the main function, should we have them all congregated at the top of the main function, or should we incorporate them within our main as we see the necessity to use them?
Content:None

Piazza Post:968

Response To:965
Subject:You could argue for either, but if you're putting them in main I'd suggest putting near where they are being used, since they have a more natural home there than they do at the top of main
Content:None

Piazza Post:977
Poster:student
Num Views:39
Type:question
Created:2014-09-15T20:53:04Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:13 people and lbs of butter
Content:i was looking at the sample run code and i don't understand why 13 people being served means you need 2 pounds of butter. if you have 13 people, then you're making about 1.083 batches. Since you need 1.5 cups of butter per batch, then you need 1.625 cups. Since 2 cups are in a lb of butter then you need 0.81 lbs of butter which rounded up is 1 lb. Why is it that the sample run says you need 2 lbs? Am I missing something obvious?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:978
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-15T20:56:39Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:977
Subject:
Content:The thing is, you cannot make a partial batch. Because you have 13 people, you will need to make 2 batches. If you need 1.5 cups of butter per batch, then 2 batches * 1.5 cups = 3 cups of butter total, bringing you up to more than one pound of butter. Because you have to buy butter by the pound and one pound of butter only provides two cups, you will have to buy 2 pounds of butter.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:979
Poster:student
Num Views:25

Piazza Post:980
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-16T00:44:20Z

Endorsements:0
Response To:979
Subject:
Content:The style grader is still being debugged and is not the absolute authority on acceptable style. Please follow the style guide to the letter, as this is the standard to which projects will be graded. In the style guide there is a section titled things to never do, and one of the items is never use global variables. It would be best to move any to inside your main() function.

Piazza Post:984
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-16T00:04:52Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:983
Subject:
Content:yes you do need to add comments! you need them to explain what your code is doing, because otherwise it can be really confusing. and yes, that'll be part of your style grade. --- Purpose of comments is so that, say you email your code to your friend who knows NOTHING about code; they should be able to get a feel for what the code is doing SOLELY by reading the comments. Well, okay, maybe not THAT much, but that's what comments are for. Imagine you look at your project1 code a year later... will you be able to understand what you were thinking when you wrote said code a year ago? ... actually, <link> an xkcd comic came out just today that's sorta relevant... XD

Piazza Post:1008

Subject:Autograder code guess
Content:Just doing some reading on Zyante, and I now think the code of autograder could be really simple is it start with "#include "cupcakes.h"" and then you just assert a bunch of data and let the computer do the comparing, could it be as simple as this?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1009
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-16T01:25:23Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:1008
Subject:
Content:It's certainly more complicated than that. You don't just want to check if your program produces the correct output. You'd also want to check if your program is stylistically, syntactically, and semantically correct, and is non-trivial (i.e., does not just print things that have been fed to it). We also make sure your code doesn't do anything malicious.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1010

Piazza Post:1012
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-16T02:12:53Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1011
Subject:
Content:I think int should be fine. Because you have already round it up to an integer, it wouldn't matter what you assign it -- the ceil function returns a double, though, so you might get a warning about storing a double in an int and losing accuracy, but all you need to do for that is put (int) or static_case<int> right before ceil
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1022

Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Const vs. double
Content:For things like the cost of flour, etc and the number of cups in a batch, is it preferable to use const or double for declaring those?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1023
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-16T02:37:54Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1022
Subject:
Content:You actually want both, a const double. double means that it can handle decimals (or large numbers). const means that its value does not change during the program. In this case, you want both of those things.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1024
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None

Content:don't forget the common style of a const is ALL_UPPERCASE_WITH_UNDERSCORES_BETWEEN_WORDS.

Subject:Declaration and Definition Arrangement Question
Content:In terms of arranging integer or double declarations and definitions, should we declare/define them all in one section near the beginning of the main() function, or can we break it up per each section that the integer or double is relevant? For example, if we were declaring a double and assigning an equation to it, could we place it right above the section that prints out that value, or should it be with all the other declarations near the top of the main() function? --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1029
Poster:student
Num Views:18
Type:question
Created:2014-09-16T02:40:38Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:"Smallest scope possible?"
Content:The style guide says that we must "Declare variables in the smallest scope possible." What exactly does that mean?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1030
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-16T03:50:43Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1029
Subject:
Content:declare variables right before they are needed
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1031
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-16T03:52:49Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1029
Subject:
Content:from a earlier post.............................. It's actually a matter of functionality. The rule is you should create a variable in the smallest scope possible (scope is something we'll be talking about in lecture soon). So the best time to create a global constant would be when you need a variable visible across multiple files, or multiple functions (in other words, a global scope). However, if you only need it in one function (in this case, you only need it in main), declaring them in only that function is more preferable. However, we won't take off points either way in this case, since we would like for you to become accustomed to global constants for future projects.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1066
Poster:student
Num Views:51
Type:question
Created:2014-09-16T15:56:47Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:if/else
Content:let's say i have three variables, a, b, c. I want to write something that says, basically, "if a is the minimum of a, b, c, <do this>, else if b is the minimum of a, b, c, <do this>, else if c is the minimum of a, b, c, <do this>. " is there a minimum value function or something equivalent? I looked online, discovered std::min, but am still pretty confused on how it works
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1067
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-16T16:03:09Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:1066
Subject:
Content:std::min is a function that takes two values and returns the lesser of the two. So if you had int a = 4, b = 5; cout << min(a, b); it would print 4. The way you could could work this into the logic you're describing above is figure out what the min of a and b are (we'll call this min1), and then figure out if min1 or c is the lesser of the two (we'll call this result). Then you could do your selection on result see if it is equal to a, b, or c
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1075
Poster:student
Num Views:33
Type:question
Created:2014-09-16T20:11:14Z
Tags:zyante
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:#include
Content:Why do we need to use the #include directive to command the preprocessor the look in its library for, say, <cmath>. Why aren't cmath functions just automatically available to be used?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1076
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-16T22:39:39Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1075
Subject:
Content:The designers of C++ decided not to automatically include libraries to allow for faster compile time. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1079

Subject:"declare variables in the smallest scope possible"
Content:Saw this in the style guide- can someone please explain in greater detail what this means?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1084
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-16T21:37:47Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1083
Subject:
Content:Basically, this means declaring a variable right before you need it! So instead of, say, declaring all of your constants before the main function, you declare them within the main function wherever they're relevant.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1087

Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Spitting out the wrong answer
Content:So for some reason when I enter 48 people to feed my program keeps telling me that I need to have 4 pounds of butter, even though my "pounds of butter needed" is equal to the number of batches needed (4) divided by 4/3, which comes out to exactly three. I'm sure there must be some weird math thing I'm not getting. I just can't figure out what. I have it entered as: (numBatches / (4/3)); Where numBatches = 4.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1088
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-16T23:32:40Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1087
Subject:
Content:time for some "fun" with division in c++... the division operator, /, works differently for integers as for doubles. when dividing two integers, / will give the quotient only. ex. 5 / 2 = 2 but if at least one of the values is a double, we get the value we expect. ex. 5.0 / 2 = 2.5 ex. 5 / 2.0 = 2.5 ex. 5.0 / 2.0 = 2.5 so what is 4 / 3 ? not what you are expecting...
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:how to get pluralize to print
Content:Hello! I'm trying to fully grasp pluralize and still having some trouble. I understand that the general format is as such: cout << pluralize("single", "plural", "variable") and I am even able to get the "single" or "plural" correctly as an answer, but not as an output printed out in the sentence I want. How do I get the output from pluralize to be part of my sentence?? thanks for any help
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1111
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-17T02:23:18Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1110
Subject:
Content:if you have int val = 3; cout << pluralize("single", "plural", val) << endl; it will output plural on val = 1; cout << pluralize("single", "plural", val) << endl; will output single hope this helps
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1112
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-17T02:24:48Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1110
Subject:it doesn't output that value into the rest of my sentence for some reason and I don't understand why 
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1113
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-17T03:12:04Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1110
Subject:The pluralize function only prints the singular or plural form of the word. It does not print the value. For example, int val = 3; cout << pluralize("single", "plural", val) << endl; // this prints "plural" If you want it to print out "3 plural", you need to print the value first: cout << val << " " << pluralize("single", "plural", val) << endl; // this prints "3 plural" I hope this clarifies.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1114
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-17T03:18:53Z
Tags:

Piazza Post:1126
Poster:student
Num Views:38
Type:question
Created:2014-09-17T13:31:38Z
Tags:project1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Trouble w/ ceil() function
Content:I'm using the ceil function to calculate number of batches that need to be made: batches= ceil(numPeople/CUPCAKES_PER_BATCH); batches is an int and I made CUPCAKES_PER_BATCH a const int equal to 12 . For some reason, it doesn't correctly compile unless the #of people is an even multiple of 12. Also, if using ceil, does my output need to include it as well or can I just type batches? ex: cout << ceil(batches); Thanks
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1127
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-17T13:37:13Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1126
Subject:
Content:Is numPeople also an int? In that case it's because you're dividing two integers, which will automatically give back an integer value. So if numPeople = 18, for instance, numPeople/CUPCAKES_PER_BATCH is going to equal 1, and then ceil(1) is still 1. What you want to do is declare one of those two variables as a double, so you get a double value after dividing, and then use ceil() afterward.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1128
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-17T21:30:11Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1126
Subject:
Content:You need to cast one of the variables to a double, to avoid integer division. You do not need to call ceil() again when you output. And for future reference, use dummy variables. Do not post project code on Piazza.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1137

Response To:-1
Subject:Cupcake project, perfect output but not working???
Content:What is the major functions and commands this program needs? I used double and pluralize ( if function ). and the output matches perfectly do you know what could be causing the submit to confuse. I received 0/50 on monday.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1138
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-17T16:51:48Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1137
Subject:
Content:By matched perfectly, do you mean you checked with a difference checker like quickdiff and there were no differences? or do you mean the values were the same. because if it's the latter, it's possible you have a typo of some sort that causes none of your outputs to match any of the expected outputs to match and causes you to receive a 0.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1139
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-17T16:53:44Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1137
Subject:
Content:Put your output and the expected output in a diffchecker (such as <link> diffchecker.com or <link> quickdiff) and compare the outputs. The only reason you will receive a 0 out of 50 is you are calculating and printing the wrong numbers, or you have a word(s) spelled incorrectly.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1143
Poster:instructor

Created:2014-09-17T17:48:11Z

Endorsements:1
Response To:1142
Subject:
Content:The autograder site will tell you whether or not the submission was accepted, but you will not receive any form of email confirmation.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:Codelab 10643
Content:I'm not sure where to start on this codelab question: toThePowerOf is a function that accepts two <link> int <link> parameters and returns the <link> value of the first <link> parameter raised to the power of the second. An <link> int <link> variable cubeSide has <link> already been <link> declared and <link> initialized . Another <link> int <link> variable , cubeVolume , has <link> already been <link> declared . Write a <link> statement that calls toThePowerOf to compute the <link> value of cubeSide raised to the power of 3, and <link> store this <link> value in cubeVolume .

Piazza Post:1147
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-18T14:58:37Z

Endorsements:0
Response To:1144
Subject:Think about what that first statement you have written is doing; you're calling the function which returns the value you want. But what are you doing with the value the function returns? Remember, the return value of a function only exists in the statement it's called in.

Piazza Post:1150
Poster:student
Num Views:44
Type:question
Created:2014-09-17T19:56:20Z
Tags:other
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Career Fair
Content:It was mentioned today that the career fair next week offered internships to students in a class as basic as mine. I intend on majoring in CS, and so by the summer I should have EECS 280 under my belt as well. My resume is filled with good work experience, and I have coded projects on my own in the past. Is it recommended that I go, given my past experience? My main hope is to get an internship for the summer. The only reason I ask is the cost of getting necessary materials (I didn't bring my suit; it'd have to be shipped to Ann Arbor) so as to attend. Any additional information you could provide would be excellent.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1151
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-17T20:38:39Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1150
Subject:
Content:In regards to needing your suit Don't worry. I wore a suit last year, and while I felt a bit more confident in it, I also felt a bit awkward. Personally, I think that as long as you are dressed respectably (no jeans with holes, wear a button down shirt, khakis/slacks, maybe a dressy sweater, something along the lines of business casual) will do just fine. Honestly, I see absolutely no trade-off (aside from giving up a little time) to going and at least trying to get the internship and handing out resumes. The worst that happens, is they say they no or that you aren't currently qualified (which would change with more course work). And if they say no, you're in the same position as if you never went at all. So I say take a chance and go for it! You get some experience with handing out resumes and being at a career fair, and you may even get an internship out of it!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:Autograder grading

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1160
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-17T22:15:19Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1159
Subject:
Content:Failing one test will not necessarily make you fail subsequent tests. But there may be a bug or a typo in your code that results in a failure of multiple tests.

Piazza Post:1163
Poster:student
Num Views:69
Type:question
Created:2014-09-18T06:35:24Z
Tags:codelab
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Codelab 11111
Content:Here is my answer, but it cannot work: c == ( endl ) || ( \t ) || (' ') The result shows that t is not defined. I am not sure how can we use the whitespace character. <link> Assume that c is a <link> char <link> variable that has been <link> declared and <link> already <link> given a <link> value . Write an <link> expression whose <link> value is <link> true if and only if c is what is called a <link> whitespace <link> character (that is a space or a tab or a newline-- none of which result in ink being printed on paper).
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1164
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-18T13:07:14Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1163
Subject:
Content:\t is a character, which means you need to wrap it in single quotes (because that makes it a character literal). And you can't compare a character to endl as that isn't a character. And you can't chain operators, such as saying c==' ' || '\t', you need to explicitly make comparisons: c==' ' || c=='\t'
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1199

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1200
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-19T12:48:30Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1199
Subject:
Content:As long as you click on "go to the next section", your answers are saved If you "refresh" while you are still within the section, I don't know if your answers are saved or not. You can go to "home" and it will give you a scoreboard on what you have done. on a refresh, your answers are blanked. This way you can use zybooks as a review for exams. It would not be a good review tool if your answers were already there.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1216
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-19T19:13:41Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1215
Subject:
Content:80 and under is the standard if they are slightly over, that will also be OK once they start hitting 85, you should pay attention and decide if they need to be shortened 90 and over are NOT acceptable Think of driving on the interstate and what is "really" the speed limit. Most interpret it as how fast can I go and not get a ticket. Most agree 71 or 72 is safe. But at what point isn't it? Same here
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1227
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-20T15:14:07Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1226
Subject:
Content:you are correct. debugIt.cpp we wrote to be very confusing on the code part of it. We didn't want students to figure out what the code does and to be able to give us the line numbers from just reading the code. The point of that part is to force you to use the debugger to answer the questions. We want you to learn how to use a debugger. It will save you hours and hours and hours during this course. So for debugIt.cpp, don't even attempt to figure out the code
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Response To:1239
Subject:
Content:testMax should somehow "test out" several test cases of max within the body of the function. It doesn't need any input, as it is just being used to test drive the max function. Also, make sure you are spelling all function names exactly as codelab spells them!

Piazza Post:1241
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-21T00:41:59Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1239
Subject:
Content:testMax takes no arguments max takes two arguments you should be able to have max(2,2) and get the correct value back why would you want testMax to have a function as part of the arguments? This question is how do you test another function. You test a function by calling it with different values

Piazza Post:1243
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-21T02:36:48Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1239
Subject:I finally got it. What I learned from stumbling through this one for awhile: Most important: Don't overthink it.Incorporate only a *few* different cases for the two numbers. Think about all the possible ways that two numbers can be compared, then evolve your test cases from this intuition.Also, utilizing relational operators is necessary.Throwing in a "catch-all" return statement at the end would not be a bad idea, either. Best of luck!
Content:None

Piazza Post:1249
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-22T22:18:02Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1239
Subject:This problem is trying to get you to understand how one might create a method that tests different possible cases for a function. For example, the method max(int a, int b) has three possible test cases: Is a > b?is a < b?Is a = b? The problem wants you to input these three test cases as code, probably within if statements. In other words, your code should end up having three sets of conditionals corresponding to each possible test case. As a heads up, 11151 will end up having nine test cases. I very much dislike how problems 11150 and 11151 are posed, and I feel these two problems are actually destructive to the learning experience rather than helpful, evidenced by how many people are having trouble with it. I would very much rather have you guys understand what the problem is trying to teach you and quickly move on rather than needlessly waste time agonizing over a bad question. :/
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1260
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-23T02:55:46Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1255
Subject:You step into the code, follow line numbers, and see when it reaches the "return" statement of the function (that has line 66 as its last line). Now, the last line number that the debugger visits in that function (just when returning), will be the last one. And this line number will be less than 66.

Piazza Post:1274

Tags:lecture
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Double variable imprecision
Content:Could someone explain further why double variables are imprecise? I don't understand why in the lecture example the program couldn't output 0.1 with 20 decimal places and instead added a 555 on the end.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1275
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-21T19:30:27Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1274
Subject:
Content:think of 1/3 what is the exact representation of it? how many double numbers are there? but remember there are only a finite number of bits to represent those infinite number of values. Cannot be done
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1276
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-21T20:29:04Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1274
Subject:I get why 1/3 is imprecise, but why can't a double variable represent 1/10?
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1277
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-21T21:03:56Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1274
Subject:This is so because while doubles are displayed in base 10, they are saved in binary in memory. In base two, you can not be absolutely accurate in the representation of 1/10 the same way you can not accurately represent 1/3 in decimal in base 10.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1278
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-21T21:27:04Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1274
Subject:Oh okay. That makes sense, thank you. So is the 555 like a rounding error?
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1295
Poster:student
Num Views:43

Created:2014-09-22T00:43:54Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Scope issues
Content:I am starting project 2, and I am starting to define the first getName function, and I am running into some issues. I am able to ask for the names, get the prompts and everything, but I wanted to know how I can call those names back in the main function or other functions without having to prompt the system again? I know that you can't call a variable to main from inside another function because of the function's scope, but I don't know how else to use those names outside of the getName function, and I know we aren't supposed to use global variables. Help?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1296
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-22T02:15:27Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:1295
Subject:
Content:You need to be returning those values from getName(). That way, in your main function, you can have a call to getName that looks like this: p1_name = getName(1); This will set up a variable in main() that holds the result (what got returned) from getName().
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1307
Poster:student
Num Views:5
Type:question
Created:2014-09-22T02:46:54Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Global Variables
Content:It says that 25 points will be detected for global variables, what exactly are they? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1308
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-22T02:50:41Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1307
Subject:
Content:Global variables are those that are declared outside of any functions. They are dangerous since any function can access and modify. // global variable int x; void foo(); int main() { // local variable int y; // main() can modify x because it is global x = 0; // main() cannot modify z because it is local to foo() } void foo() { // local variable int z; // foo() can modify x because it is global x = 1; // foo() cannot modify y because it is local to main() } Global constants, by contrast, are generally fine.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1309
Poster:student

Piazza Post:1356
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-24T02:15:55Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1351
Subject:11150 requires three separate test cases: 0,0 = t/f? 0,1 = t/f? 1,0 = t/f? 11151 requires NINE test cases: 0,0,0 = t/f? 0,0,1 = t/f? 0,1,0 = t/f? 0,1,1 = t/f? 1,0,0 = t/f? 1,0,1 = t/f? 1,1,0 = t/f? 1,1,1 = t/f? It's up to you to code that in as conditionals and determine whether you should compare them to true or false.
Content:None

Piazza Post:1361
Poster:student
Num Views:9
Type:question
Created:2014-09-22T22:52:15Z
Tags:lecture
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Boolean v Int
Content:This is a test I did on Xcode based on an example in class. I was wondering what would the value be if I had the (a > b); statement from class in a function's return statement. I got that it was 1. What I thought was really weird was that even if I didn't change any of the function declaration and just changed it to bool instead of int it also returned 1 without an error! How is that so? Do 0 and 1 act as both booleans and ints? <image> 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1362
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-22T22:58:55Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1361
Subject:
Content:There is an implicit conversion from bool to int, which is what you're seeing. The same as saying double d = 5; // int is implicitly converted to double And indeed, 0 and 1 both act as booleans as well as ints. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1387
Poster:student
Num Views:13
Type:question
Created:2014-09-23T21:08:49Z
Tags:codelab
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Predicate Functions
Content:Hello Can someone explain 1. What predicate functions are? 2. Why do we use them? 3. How do we use them? Thanks
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1388
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-23T21:39:16Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1387
Subject:
Content:I believe that for the purpose of this class, you can think of a predicate function as a function that takes input, and returns a bool based on what you want that function to do. Example, you could have a function that is "isOdd(int number)" This predicate function returns true or false in this case based on if the input is odd. bool isOdd(int number) { return (number % 2); } You could also have isChar, isString, isEven etc. etc. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1389

Piazza Post:1403
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-24T02:12:12Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1402
Subject:
Content:I agree that this question is terrible, but at least it is possible, albeit stupid. You need nine cases total, i.o.w. nine simple conditionals: 0,0,0 = t/f? 0,0,1 = t/f? 0,1,0 = t/f? 0,1,1 = t/f? 1,0,0 = t/f? 1,0,1 = t/f? 1,1,0 = t/f? 1,1,1 = t/f? That covers all the test cases. Not all of them evaluate to false, as some of them are correct. You have to type all that in code. Yeah, it's ridiculous. Note: Uh, whoops, flagged this as inappropriate as I was trying to edit it. My bad.

Piazza Post:1411
Poster:student
Num Views:48
Type:question
Created:2014-09-24T03:34:00Z
Tags:codelab, other
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:== vs = Question about CodeLab
Content:I am having some confusion with the use of = vs. the relational operator ==. For instance, in CodeLab 11058, the answer demands =, while in 10558, the answer demands ==. Is == just used when it specifies a boolean variable?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1412
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-24T05:39:01Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:1411
Subject:
Content:The double == is used when comparing two values/variables, usually within an if expression. Think of it as a question: If you are looking for a boolean value (true or false), then you use == to essentially ask, "is this true?" or "are they equal?" The single = is used when setting variables to a value. You aren't asking if two values are equal, you are stating that they are. Hope this helps. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1426
Poster:student
Num Views:11
Type:question
Created:2014-09-24T15:49:23Z
Tags:lecture
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:"break"
Content:is "break" in switch statements a substitute for what would be brackets in if/else statements
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1427
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-24T18:14:07Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1426
Subject:
Content:That's not really the best way to think about it. Instead, I think of it as the break ending each case and then continuing execution after the closing brace of the switch statement. p.s.: [ ] These are brackets { } These are braces (or curly braces) ( ) These are parentheses < > These are angle brackets (or individually a "greater than" or "less than" symbol)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1442
Poster:student
Num Views:17
Type:question
Created:2014-09-24T19:38:32Z
Tags:other
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:= vs. ==
Content:Let's say at the beginning of my code, I assign 4 to variable x, so x = 4. Later on, if I have an if statement that says "if (x == 4) { //do whatever}..." the complier will do whatever, correct? I thought = and == were not interchangeable?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1443
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-24T19:42:25Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1442
Subject:
Content:You are correct that = and == are not interchangeable. As you said, = performs assignment. x = 4; means that the value store is now stored in x. x == 4; gives you back a true or false boolean value depending on if the value inside of x is to equal the value 4. if (x==4){ //do whatever } will only do whatever if the value in x is equal to the value 4.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1444
Poster:student
Num Views:14
Type:question
Created:2014-09-24T19:40:59Z

Piazza Post:1460
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-24T23:48:42Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:1459
Subject:
Content:that is the beginning of the statement that starts on line 34, but the statement end on line 34? Check to see if there's a semicolon at the end of the line. If not, the statement might not end there, and that's why the debugger is "skipping" that line.

Piazza Post:1513
Poster:student
Num Views:10
Type:question
Created:2014-09-26T01:09:00Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:step into/step over/step out
Content:What does a step into/over/out really mean? I know it's debugging/looking for flaws in code, but when I set a breakpoint, run the program, then click step into, what is happening in the compiler? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1514
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-26T01:20:21Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1513
Subject:
Content:breakpoints will "break" execution on that line the line highlighted will be the next one to be executed step into will go into functions such that you can watch them execute one line at a time step over will literally go to the next statement in your code step into and step over are equivalent unless the current line has a function call step out will get out of the current function
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1515
Poster:student
