Piazza Post:1524
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-27T19:54:39Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1517
Subject:The specification is the one and only definitive place to look for rules. The spec states: If an empty name is entered, use Rocky for the Player name if it is Player 1. If it is Player 2, use Hulk. Also print ERROR: Illegal name given, using default And that means an "empty name" is invalid everything else that is entered is valid
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1525
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-27T20:02:25Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1517
Subject:I am using Windows 8.1. Eclipse 4.4.0 Cygwin GCC (g++ compiler and debugger)
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1526
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-27T21:18:05Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1517
Subject:it most likely is your compiler. Searching the web the newline in a Windows/DOS text file is CR+LF ("\r\n") - but the gygwin version of C library doesn't take CR into account when reading a line. The CR on its own will move the cursor position back to the beginning of the line.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1527
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-27T21:51:24Z

Endorsements:0

Subject:Autograder help
Content:<link> Screen_Shot_20140925_at_10.25.07_PM.png Where did I go wrong? Thank you!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1533
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-26T02:35:52Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1532
Subject:
Content:You are missing the implementation (definition) of printInitialHeader(). The autograder tests all functions by calling them, so if an implementation is missing, it's unable to compile your code.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1534
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-26T02:45:08Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1532
Subject:I already have " void printInitialHeader(); " written in there before my main. Am I supposed to include that in my main? Thanks Maxim! :)
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1535
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-26T02:52:36Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1532
Subject:That's the prototype (declaration) that goes above main(). You also need the implementation (definition) below main(). We have actually provided you with an implementation of printInitialHeader() in <link> distribution code. // prototype void printInitialHeader(); int main() { // ... } // definition void printInitialHeader() { cout << "----------------------------------------" << endl; cout << " EECS 183 " << endl; cout << " Rock-Paper-Scissors " << endl; cout << "----------------------------------------" << endl << endl; } 
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1544
Poster:instructor

Endorsements:1
Response To:1543
Subject:
Content:The RME for getMove() holds the answer to this question. What you are doing sounds correct to me. /** * Requires: player_name is the name of the player being prompted for a move. * Modifies: Nothing. * Effects : Prompts the player for their move and returns it. * This function should accept the first non-whitespace character as * the move * If an illegal character is entered for their move, print error * message 2 and return rock as a default. * Prompt : [player_name], enter your move: * Used In : doRound() */

Piazza Post:1556
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-26T16:13:51Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:1555
Subject:
Content:You must print the error message and assign the default name in getName(), as specified in the Effects clause, not in main(). /** * Requires: player_number is either 1 or 2. * Modifies: Nothing. * Effects : Prompts the user to enter their name. Names may have spaces * within them. Example: Kermit the Frog, Fozzie * If an empty name is given, print error message 1, and * return a default name. * For player 1, the default name is: Rocky * For player 2, the default name is: Hulk * Prompt : Player [player_number], enter your name: * Used In : main() */ string getName(int player_number); Also note that an empty string is a string of zero characters: "". By contrast, " " is a string of one character, so you shouldn't be checking for it.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:Style Grader
Content:The style grader says that my bool functions should be returning true or false rather than a number (1 or 0). --------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1562
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-26T20:46:29Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1561
Subject:
Content:Compilers do understand true and false, so please use them. By contrast, not all compilers understand and, or and not, so you should use &&, || and !.

Endorsements:0
Response To:1571
Subject:You're overthinking getWinCount(). First, realize that this function is generalized and it shouldn't matter if player_num is 1 or 2. Round results are either 0, 1 (player 1 won) or 2 (player 2 won). So just check if the player one each of the three rounds.

Piazza Post:1609

Num Views:None

Created:2014-09-29T14:26:45Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1604
Subject:doRound() returns the number of the player who wins the round. Use these round results in getWinCout() to get the number of wins each player has, then compare these to determine if you need to play the third round.
Content:None

Piazza Post:1630
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-28T04:09:53Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1628
Subject:What exactly is the purpose of getWinCount()? A simpler and far more efficient alternative to keep track of scores that completely bypasses the need for getWinCount() and repetitive announceWinner() calls is: // getName() and stuff above... int p1_wins = 0; int p2_wins = 0; bool cont = true; for (int i = 0; i < 3 && cont; i++){ switch(doRound()){ case 1: ++p1_wins; break; case 2: ++p2_wins; break; } if (i == 2 && (<p1 win condition> || <p2 win condition>)){ cont = false; } } // announceWinner() and stuff below. It seems really unnecessary and overly complicated being forced to use getWinCount() in two separate occasions; after second round to calculate whether or not to run a third round, and if so, having to calculate the win counts again after the third round, not to mention multiple announceWinner() calls to cover different victory cases at different times.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1631
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-28T13:44:30Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1628
Subject:Once students knows functions, knows passing of parameters, knows how to handle return values from functions, and knows for loops, I would agree with you But for Project 2, I cannot guarantee all of the above conditionals, therefore it had to be a design that addressed the goals of what we wanted the students to learn. And this at times come into direct conflict with the "best" way to solve the problem. Now if I gave this same exercise at the end of the semester, I absolutely would design it a different way.
Content:None

Piazza Post:1643
Poster:student
Num Views:15
Type:question
Created:2014-09-27T16:17:33Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Is round winner function
Content:Is the isRoundWinner function supposed to find the name of the winner? Because the variable winnerName is in the comment but I don't know where to get the winner name. I also don't understand why isRoundWinner is a bool and how to use the result. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1644
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-27T18:16:44Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1643
Subject:
Content:isRoundWinner() takes two moves (chars): move and opponent_move. It returns true if and only if move beats opponent_move and false otherwise. winner_name is not in the RME and this function does not deal with names. It is used just to tell if one move beats another.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1645
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup

Poster:instructor

Endorsements:0
Response To:1643
Subject:The RME is above the function declaration: /** * Requires: move is the move of the player being checked for a win. * opponent_move is the move of the opponent. * Modifies: Nothing. * Effects : Returns true if and only if the player who made move won. * Used In : doRound() */ bool isRoundWinner(char move, char opponent_move);

Response To:-1
Subject:when the round is a draw
Content:Do I have to make a new function that decides whether the round is draw or not? because isRoundWinner function only return true or false. which means it returns if player 1 won or player 2 won. There's no way to figure out if the round is a draw.. I'm really confused. when isRoundWinner is true, I can assign player1_name to winner name. when isRoundWinner is false, I can assign player2_name to winner name. Then, how does the compiler knows if the round is draw?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1661
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-27T19:27:10Z
Tags:
Endorsements:3
Response To:1660
Subject:
Content:When using isRoundWinner you only check if one player has won the round. Therefore, return true if the player you are checking for won, and false if they drew or lost. Then you can check outside of the function if neither player won, you know it was a draw.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1662
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-27T19:44:01Z

Subject:How do I know if neither player won? because if it's false, it means that they either drew or player 2 won.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1663
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-27T19:48:35Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1660
Subject:Test if both players won in main. If they both return false, it's a draw.
Content:None

Piazza Post:1668
Poster:student
Num Views:7
Type:question
Created:2014-09-27T20:28:32Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Control may reach end of Non Void Function
Content:"Control may reach end of Non Void Function" What does this mean at the end of one of my function definitions? I am using X Code. Thanks
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1669
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-27T20:35:25Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1668
Subject:
Content:This occurs when you write a function where the return statement may not be reached. if you write... int foo (int x) { if (x > 0) { return x; } } Your code may never reach the return statement because x might not be greater than zero. You may be missing some kind of default return statement that would fix this error.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1677

Response To:1676
Subject:

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1678
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-27T20:53:54Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1676
Subject:
Content:The student's answer in incorrect. You cannot have an empty char, just like you can't have an empty int, which must always have some value. The player will always enter a move (see @500), you just have to check that the move is valid. Note that strings are special in that they are sequences of characters of variable length&#8212;they can have zero or more characters. So you can have an empty string: "" (but not an empty char).
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1685
Poster:student
Num Views:5
Type:question
Created:2014-09-27T21:27:00Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Losing player_num after getWinCount
Content:In debugging my program, player_num gets through getWinCount properly (image 2), but when it's taken back up to the main, it reverts to 0 (image 3). I've added and run some outputs with the r1_result & r2_result and those save and print correctly through main. Why would I be losing my player_num assignment? It causes my program to output "No winner!" every time :( Here's the sequence in images of what happens, any insight would be greatly appreciated! (I'm sorry if these pictures end up being less innocuous than I presumed!) Before passing through getWinCount ------- at the end of getWinCount ------------ being brought back to main <image> width="259" height="130" <image> width="243" height="131" <image> width="254" height="130" 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1686
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-27T21:46:46Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1685
Subject:
Content:player_num is local to getWinCount(), so unless you define player_num in main(), main() doesn't know that player_num exists. When getWinCount() returns, all of its variables are deleted from memory. If you do not assign the return value of getWinCount() to a variable, that value is lost. Also, player_num is the number of the player for whom you're counting the number of wins and getWinCout() must return the number of rounds that player has won.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1716
Poster:student
Num Views:4
Type:question
Created:2014-09-27T23:00:15Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Style Grader Issues
Content:The style grader is reporting "iincorrect spacing" around symbols such as "+" and "-" that are within strings. I don't think this is intentional. Also, despite return 0; and return 1; being valid for bool functions, the style grader demands returning a value of true or false.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1717
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-27T23:19:15Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1716
Subject:
Content:Disregard spacing if it's inside a string. There already have been several of questions about this, so please search. Though returning 0 or 1 will compile and give you a correct solution, this is not the best style. Please use true and false as we instruct you in the <link> Style Guide. There's a reason they were introduced in C++.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:Transferring values from function to function
Content:I've been having some troubles transferring values from function due to the comment in the grading rubric that stats "25 points will be deducted if you use global variables" (I'm taking that as you can't declare any variables inside of main). If that's not what it means, please let me know, as my problem will be solved. Otherwise: I'm using the getName function to get the names of each player participating. string getName(int player_number); I then notice that the function doRound() int doRound(string p1_name, string p2_name); requires the names of each player to process, however getName() and doRound() are two different functions. How would I go about transferring the names obtained in getName() to the function doRound()? At first, I tried the following doRound(getName(1), getName(2); Which works fine. but with the function int getWinCount(int player_num, int r1_result, int r2_result, int r3_result); I put, for example getWinCount(1, doRound(getMove(getName(1)), getMove(getName(2)), doRound(getMove(getName(1)), getMove(getName(2)), doRound(getMove(getName(1)), getMove(getName(2))); Which works fine, but since I use the getline() function in getName() it asks for the player's name every time it is called (so 3 times), something we don't want. What would be the best way to approach this? (Transfering values from function to function and fixing the getline() problem with getName()) Maybe my problem isn't what I think it is and there's an easier/obvious way to fix that I'm not aware of?

Content:I could be wrong, but global variables are those declared OUTSIDE of main, not inside. Those declared within should be fair game.

Poster:instructor

Endorsements:1
Response To:1736
Subject:
Content:global variable are declared ABOVE main() not within main() variables declared within main() are local to the main() function are perfectly fine

Subject:Huh, so it's just common practice, then. That's a somewhat unsatisfactory answer... :/ It's a nuance reading the description of something I don't know, being forced to look at the end of the description just to see what it is the description is describing. I'd be much better if the declaration was at the top, and the definition below it, so at least we can see what the RME's trying to describe. Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1751
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-28T14:10:34Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1746
Subject:RME's only go with the declarations. They never are with the definitions. I believe it is common practice because you need to know the information within the RME in order to implement the function. Also you need it in order to call the function correctly. So if that info is what is most important, why not put it first? If you like them below the function declaration, then move them all.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1768
Poster:student
Num Views:22
Type:question
Created:2014-09-28T03:55:47Z
Tags:other
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Why are while(true) loop, break, and continue not allowed?
Content:These are all extremely useful utilities that can greatly improve the efficiency and the flow of code, particularly in situations where repeated instances of something which could have multiple instances for termination, or skipping parts of a loop that are not necessary. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1769
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-28T13:36:57Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1768
Subject:
Content:it is not allowed in this course because before I banned it I would see it for almost every loop. And the students would not think about what the conditional needed to be to end the loop and then they would have 3-4-5-6-7 break or continue statement within their loop. They hacked it together instead of thinking about it. I prefer to force students into actually thinking about what the condition needs to be to end the loop. And yes you are correct, once you fully understand a while loop, break and continue can be very useful. But my experience is those are very over-used. And again, it is because it is "easier" to not really think about what the conditional needs to be. Efficiency and flow of code never go above readability. Besides you have an optimizing compiler that will most of the time do a better job than you can do on your own when it comes to optimizing code. Therefore again, go for readability
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1770

Response To:-1
Subject:If whitespace is entered for player name
Content:When the user doesn't enter any name (they hit the ENTER key) my program will show the error message, but I haven't been able to figure out how to make the error message show up if the user enters a whitespace (like if they hit the space bar or a tab). The player's name just shows up as a space. I have tried to use isspace... if ( playerName.empty() || isspace(playerName) ) {} but my compiler keeps showing the error "No matching function for call to 'isspace'. And I have made sure to include the appropriate headers. Are you guys worried about bad data checking that includes whitespace or is it only for empty inputs? If you guys are worried about whitespace, how do I use isspace correctly?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1787
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-28T13:28:32Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:1786
Subject:
Content:From the spec, the rule is: "To earn full credit for this project, your program must adhere to the following rules for bad data checking: If an empty name is entered, use Rocky for the Player name if it is Player 1. If it is Player 2, use Hulk. Also print ERROR: Illegal name given, using default" Note: spaces entered for a name is NOT empty and is therefore not an error
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1790
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-28T13:26:50Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1789
Subject:
Content:all of these are good resources and are the taped lectures and posted materials for the lectures. I would also suggest reading the email you received back from the autograder. It will give you full disclosure for the first test you fail. Figure out what the difference is between your output and the autograders, figure out what is causing the difference. Test your code to make sure it covers the case used by the autograder. etc
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:Accounting for the possibility of the first two rounds being draws

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1795
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-28T15:11:41Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1794
Subject:
Content:yes, check to see if there is a winner after 2 rounds yes, check if there are two draws yes, if needed run a 3rd round yes, on round 3 there could also be a draw yes, the autograder checks for all of these situations

Piazza Post:1817
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-28T16:44:41Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1816
Subject:
Content:Do you have two files in your project, each with a main() function? For example, if you are using Xcode and open a new project, it will automatically give you a file named main.cpp that has a main() function in it. This file must be deleted from the project. Make sure that the file given to you for debugging is the only file included in the project.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:1864

Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1861
Subject:You have two players, so you have to first tell the function which player you are assigning your name to, and it will assign 1 name for each player (2 names total). The parameter within the function determines which player you are naming. Hope that helps.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1865
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-28T19:37:59Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1861
Subject:The function must ask that player for his or her name. So if you pass in the number 1, it will print Player 1, enter your name: If you pass in the number 2, it will print Player 2, enter your name: It will then get the name from the user and return it. If the user just hits enter without typing anything else, this function will print an error and return one of the default names based on the player number.
Content:None

Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Checking problem
Content:I meet a problem. When I run my program, I type more than one char in the move part, and my program will skip the next entering move part. For example: when I enter rr, xx, enter your move: rr and the next line will become x, enter your move: This round is a draw! when I use auto-grader, it shows everything is right, but I still feel confuse. I have no idea how to solve this problem. Thank you. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1895
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-28T20:54:56Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1894
Subject:
Content:Don't worry about this. The autograder will not use such input and you'll learn more about I/O later in the semester. EDIT: getMove() function should accept the first non-whitespace character as the move. In your example, "rr" should be accepted into a string variable, not a char. Once you store "rr" in a string, you extract the first character using at() function (Zyante Chapter 4.9). This first character should be examined in isMoveGood() function. If the move is good, you return it from getMove(). Otherwise, you print error message 2, and return 'r' from getMove().
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1896
Poster:student
Num Views:36
Type:question
Created:2014-09-28T21:05:49Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:doRound function
Content:I know we are supposed to use the announceRound Winner and the isRoundWinner in the doRound function, but how exactly do we implement these into the function? I can only figure out how to do it so that player 1 always wins...
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1897
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-28T21:43:58Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:1896
Subject:
Content:After you get both moves, you need logic to decide who won. You have three possible scenarios: player 1 won, player 2 won or it was a draw. Here's one possible way to think about it: isRoundWinner will tell you if one of the players won. Given two moves, how would you tell if it was a draw? Then, if you have checked for a draw and if a player won, you could say if neither the player won nor it was a draw, we know that the other player must have won. Think about how you might construct that into a logic statement.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1898
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-29T01:27:21Z
Tags:

How can I work around this and use the moves I have already determined and apply them to the doRound function instead of having to ask again?

Response To:1900
Subject:
Content:Even if you have only one statement in an if-clause, you must enclose that single statement within braces. And those braces should follow appropriate bracing style.

Piazza Post:1921
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer

Piazza Post:1964
Poster:student
Num Views:22
Type:question
Created:2014-09-29T02:06:08Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:getWinCount
Content:I have no idea where to even start for getWinCount! I get that you need to input values for the player numbers and each possible result from each round, but what exactly is this function supposed to be returning to main? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1965
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-29T02:10:22Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1964
Subject:
Content:The flow of code for getWinCount() should be something like this: 1) Give it results for previous rounds. 2) Calculate number of rounds for each player. 3) Return number of rounds won for requested player. For example: // Round 1 and round 2 have already been played. cout << "How many rounds has player 1 won?" << endl; int p1_wins = getWinCount(...); cout << "Ahh, player 1 won " p1_wins " times!" << endl; 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1966
Poster:student

Type:followup

Piazza Post:1967
Poster:student

Endorsements:0
Response To:1964
Subject:I'm not sure this will help but remember that the doRound function returns an int.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:1968
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-29T03:05:55Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:1964
Subject:Yes, and doRound() should return the number of the winning player: 1 for player 1, 2 for player 2, and 0 for draw. Save those values and utilize them when you use getWinCount(). Consider the return values for doRound() as records for the score sheet, if you will.
Content:None

Subject:isRoundWinner options
Content:Bools only return true/false so what do we put in bool isRoundWinner? So far, I have all the options that would make it true that player 1 is the winner, but what would I do for player 2 as the winner and ties?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2008
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-29T04:22:29Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2007
Subject:
Content:bool isRoundWinner(char move, char opponent_move); isRoundWinner returns true if move beats opponent_move, not if player 1 beats player 2. You are free to pass either player's move into either parameter
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Response To:-1
Subject:Steve vs Hodor the redemption (test 17)
Content: When I submitted to the autograder, I only failed test 17. From what I can tell, my program executed two rounds and terminated, saying that hodor won the entire game even though steve and hodor each won a round each. I'm not sure what is causing this error. <image> 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2013
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-29T04:42:26Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2012
Subject:
Content:Definitely looks like a logic error concerning your calculation of whether someone has won the match or not. Keep in mind that the win condition for two rounds is ONLY if one of the players has won both. One win and a draw does not count as an overall win. Go through your code EXTREMELY THOROUGHLY and try to find what the problematic test case is. This will require some deep thinking, or the use of the handy debugger to solve. I would expect the error to be in one of two places: - Code that checks if a third round is necessary or not. - getWinCount() and/or code determining how many wins a player has.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2014
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-29T04:50:22Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2012
Subject:You're right! I accidentally said that player 2 wins the whole game if they won "round 2 and round 2" instead of "round 1 and round 2." Thanks!

Piazza Post:2020
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-29T05:35:56Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2019
Subject:
Content:Seems like something is causing your error message to print way more than needed. Maybe you aren't putting a return statement where it needs to be so some of your lines of code are read more than they should be and it prints out a lot of error message. Or maybe you are reading in more than the first non-whitespace character and aren't throwing the rest of the input to junk, so it "leaks" and it reads in multiple character inputs and they're all invalid so it prints the error many many times (once per character, for example "touhou" would read 6 times as invalid") Or perhaps something else, but hopefully that gets you some ideas!

Piazza Post:2030
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-29T06:13:23Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2029
Subject:
Content:For isRoundWinner, there should be a few if statements there covering all possible combinations of inputs of rock/paper/scissors, and in each if statement it should return a value of 0, 1, or 2. (1 means player 1 got a point, 2 means player 2 got a point, 0 means draw). Also in each if statement there should be a line that prints out who won that round. Some reason it keeps going to the case that says no one won... Sorry if I'm stating the obvious but that shouldn't be tricky to get right, and that's all I can think of :( (Btw that return value of 0 or 1 or 2 will be used to let you count the wins for getWinCount, the important part here is the print statement)

Piazza Post:2039

Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:RME's?
Content:Do I need additional RME's for the definitions of my functions below main? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2040
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-29T14:28:06Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2039
Subject:
Content:RME's should go with function prototypes above main, not with implementations/definitions below main(). If you decide to create your own function, you'll need to add additional RME's for those functions.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2043
Poster:student
Num Views:6
Type:question
Created:2014-09-29T14:55:42Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Question for debugit
Content:I wonder the questions for debugIt is given continuously or separately? I mean when we do the Q4&amp;#xff0c; do we need to start again to put a breakpoint on line 37 or just after putting a breakpoint on line34? Do we need to repeat the line numbers of all code visited/evaluated in Q2 to answer in Q4? Thank you.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2044
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-29T15:08:59Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2043
Subject:
Content:No. You should not repeat line numbers from a previous question for the next question unless explicitly specified. The questions are written to be done sequentially. That is, in one series of stepping through (step through for a question, set a breakpoint for the next, continue stepping through). If you stop and start the debugger mode, you should remove the breakpoint from the previous question and add the new breakpoint specified.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2045

Response To:-1
Subject:Project 2 FAQs!
Content:These questions came up in office hours yesterday a lot. Here's some answers and tips. Using/Calling Functions: Syntax: getName(1); // right! string getName(1); // wrong string getName(int 1); // wrong getName(int 1); // wrong There are LOTS of examples in lecture. Please review class slides! Don't forget to STORE/SAVE these values: getName(1); // wrong (result disappears into a black, mysterious hole never to be seen again) string name = getName(1); // result now stored in the string called name int round1 = doRound(player1, player2); // result of round now stored in round1 Don't forget the return types of the functions: int doRound(int p1_name, int p2_name); // doRound returns an integer value Writing and Using getWinCount(player_num, r1_result, r2_result, r3_result) This function counts the number of times player_num (1 or 2) has won between r1_result, r2_result, r3_result You can use a variable to keep the count in the function and increment it when appropriate. The function should then return this value. Compare player_num to each r1_result, r2_result and r3_result to see if they won r1_result, r2_result, r3_result hold the number of the player that won that round (0 for draw, 1 for player 1, or 2 for player 2)What logical comparison tells us if player_num won r1_result or r2_result or r3_result? This function can be used to determine who (if anyone) has won the game. You can do so by comparing the value of getWinCount( ... ) for player 1 against the getWinCount( ... ) for player 2. = vs == There is a HUGE difference between these two! Not only is this important for the project but it is also a popular exam question. Make sure that you are not accidently using = for logical comparison: if(name = "") { } // wrong (name is now equal to the empty string, "") if(name == "") { } // right! Checking if a String is Empty The empty string is represented with "" not " " (no space) Code Organization Please put your function implementations below int main(). There are comments in the project files that specify exactly how to format your code. Here's an example for one function (you would do the same format for there rest of the functions): void announceWinner(string winner_name); // prototype ABOVE the main functions int main() { string name = "Ryan"; announceWinner(name); } // Implementation BELOW int main() void announceWinner(string winner_name) { // code for announceWinner } In addition to this post, please don't forget to check lecture slides and Piazza when you run into a problem. If you do come to office hours, try to have as precise or exact of a question as possible so we can best help you. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Response To:-1
Subject:global variable
Content:Does the variable which is used in doRound function but not used in the main function count as a global variable?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2061
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-29T17:15:19Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2060
Subject:
Content:A global variable is a variable that is declared outside of a block and has scope throughout the whole program. In other words, if the variable is declared within main or within any of the subsequent functions, it is not global.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2076
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-29T18:09:44Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2075
Subject:
Content:Consider nested loops or switch cases. For example, if I had a function returnNumPlusOne(int num)... /** Requires: num is either a value of 0, 1, or 2. *** Modifies: Nothing. *** Effects: Returns num + 1 using very unnecessary switch-case code structure. **/ int returnMyNumber(int num){ switch(num){ case 0: return 1; case 1: return 2; case 2: return 3; default: cout << "MISTAKE" << endl; return 0; } } In the case of isRoundWinner(), you need many conditionals to cover all the possibilities: Rock vs. Rock = draw. Rock vs. Paper = loss. Rock vs. Scissor = win. Paper vs. Rock = win. etc. etc. etc.

Piazza Post:2080
Poster:student
Num Views:14
Type:question
Created:2014-09-29T18:14:36Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Project 2 Style Guidelines Question
Content:The style guidelines state: Acceptable: 1) RME&#8217;s with declarations before int main() Definitions after int main() 2) RME&#8217;s with definitions before int main() NOT Acceptable 1) RME&#8217;s with declarations before int main() Definitions before int main() 2) RME&#8217;s removed What exactly does that mean (especially the word RME)?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2081
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-29T18:21:28Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2080
Subject:
Content:Uhh.... there are many other posts that answer this question, but for your sake I'll answer them here. RME stands for Requires, Modifies, and Effects. Requires is a note on what exactly the parameters for a function are looking for. For example, in Project 2, the Requires for getName() is: "int player_num? should be either 1 or 2." Modifies means it's changing something. For now, this is irrelevant for us; we haven't learned how to modify something in this sense yet. Effects is a brief explanation of what the function does. For getName(), Effects would be: "Returns the inputted name for a player" or something like that. Now, concerning the positioning of RME's: /** Requires: blah *** Modifies: blah *** Effects: blah **/ int functionA(int a, int b); int main(){ ... } int functionA(int a, int b){ ... } and: /** Requires: blah *** Modifies: blah *** Effects: blah **/ int functionA(int a, int b){ ... } int main(){ ... } are acceptable. Having NO RME's and/or putting both the declaration and definition before main() are unacceptable.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2082
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-29T19:02:22Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2080
Subject:
Content:Definitions/implementations should go after main().
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-29T19:04:39Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2080
Subject:Instructors may want to consjder revising the style guide then, if definitions above main are not allowed, if what OP wrote is how it is written on the style guide.
Content:None

Response To:-1
Subject:Style Grader vs. Legibility
Content:On the style grader it says that I should have more spaces on lines in my switches (especially nested ones) but It's a lot more legible the way I have it. Should I just listen to the style grader? ex/ This is what mine looks like switch (switch1) { case 0: switch (switch2) { case 0: switch (switch3) { case 0: switch (switch4) { case 0: case 9: This is what the style grader wants switch (switch1) { case 0: switch (switch2) { case 0: switch (switch3) { case 0: switch (switch4) { case 0: case 9:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2104
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-29T20:52:52Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2103
Subject:
Content:Looks like a bug. But nested switch statements are not the best way to design your code. Best to reconsider your logic and/or use if/else statements.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2105
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-09-29T23:37:41Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2103
Subject:On the same note, should switch cases be indented like this: switch(num){ case 0: functionA(); break; case 1: functionB(); break; default: functionC(); break; } or like this: switch(num){ case 0: functionA(); break; case 1: functionB(); break; default: functionc(); break; } This becomes relevant in the case of nested loops (which I argue as being a very nice alternative to nested if-else in this case). An example of how readable it looks when used for isRoundWinner() -- all project-specific code is removed, of course, but you can guess how it works: switch (...){ case ...: switch (...){ case ...: return ...; case ...: return ...; case ...: return ...; } case ...: switch (...){ case ...: return ...; case ...: return ...; case ...: return ...; } case ...: switch (...){ case ...: return ...; case ...: return ...; case ...: return ...; } } return ...; Note: no default cases or breaks since return takes care of it.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2106
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-30T04:23:36Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2103
Subject:This is how I'd indent a switch: switch (x) { case -1: cout << "x is -1" << endl; break; case 0: cout << "x is 0" << endl; break; case 1: cout << "x is 1" << endl; break; default: cout << "n is not -1, 0, or 1" << endl; break; } 
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2107
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-30T04:58:31Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2103
Subject:That doesn't answer my question... My question was whether the following is acceptable style, not how you personally indent it: switch(x){ case -1: cout << "x is -1" << endl; break; case 0: cout << "x is 0" << endl; break; case 1: cout << "x is 1" << endl; break; default: cout << "n is not -1, 0, or 1" <, endl; break; } 
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2108
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-30T05:26:35Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2103
Subject:Looking at that I would say it isn't good style. I much prefer Maxim's example.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2109
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-30T05:32:39Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2103
Subject:Why is it not considered good style? When coding a chain of if-else conditionals, we do not indent it like this (if-else equivalent of Maxim's code): if (x == -1){ cout << "x is -1" << endl; } else if (x == 0) { cout << "x is 0" << endl; } else if (x == 1) { cout << "x is 1" << endl; } else { cout << "n is not -1, 0, or 1" << endl; } We align else if and else on the same indent space because they are related to one another. Likewise, cases are related to switch, and the way the code is written naturally provides indent spacing for multiple statements per case, unlike else-ifs. Just as having an else-if alone makes no sense and leads one to immediately assume that an if precedes it, seeing a case implies that a switch statement precedes it as well.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2110
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-30T05:34:17Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2103
Subject:To me it seems bad because the first line of code that executes is in line with that particular case. This is different from the else if case you've described, where the condition is what's in line.

It reduces the need for unnecessarily short lines of code without disrupting the readability of said code in notable manner.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2121
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-29T21:33:28Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2120
Subject:
Content:Think about the ordering of the parameters. The function checks if move beats opponent_move. So if you pass in p1's move and then p2's move as the parameters, it tells you if if p1 is the winner or not. What would the function tell you if you called it with p2's move then p1's move? Can you combine this information with the value from the first call and figure out who the winner is from there?

Piazza Post:2155
Poster:student
Num Views:19
Type:question
Created:2014-09-30T01:07:25Z
Tags:other
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Using VOID functions
Content:What's the difference with defining a void function before int main or after int main?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2156
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-30T01:57:48Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2155
Subject:
Content:Since C++ kinda goes "top to bottom" in how it runs the code, there are some situations where you want to use a function but it hasn't been declared yet. Consider this scenario: int main(){ functionA(); } void functionA(){ ... } // Definition Since C++ runs "top-to-bottom", when it calls functionA() in main(), it has no clue what functionA() is, since it's declared all the way down below main(). Just like how if you use some variable num before you've declared it, the compiler is like, "Wuah? What's num? Nobody said there's a num yet." That is why it has to be declared before it is used: void functionA(){ ... } // Definition int main(){ functionA(); } However, if you have a bunch of functions, that top part can get really big and messy, and the all-important main() would be pushed down further and further. That's why we have the handy function prototype, which solves both problems: void functionA(); // Prototype int main(){ functionA(); } void functionA(){ ... } // Definition Now the compiler knows, "Oh, there's a functionA()! Better remember that for later." before it starts running main(). This also allows us to do something like this: void functionA(); void functionB(); int main(){ functionB(); } void functionA(){ ... // Some condition to prevent infinite looping. functionB(); } void functionB(){ ... // Some condition to prevent infinite looping. functionA(); } WIthout prototypes, this code would be impossible to compile, since functionA() uses functionB(), and vise versa. Prototypes don't bother looking at the actual definitions yet; they just tell the compiler that they exist and to remember them for later. :)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2157
Poster:student
Num Views:12
Type:question
Created:2014-09-30T01:21:43Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:running multiple times
Content:how do you make the game run for three rounds? is this something you do in int main() ?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2158
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-30T01:35:06Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2157
Subject:
Content:yeah, in int main() you have to proceed to a third round if no one has won the first two. so first you have to check if anyone has won after two rounds. otherwise, you move on to a third round. (if/else) --- Something like this (super bare-bones code to illustrate order and idea): doRound(); doRound(); if (...) { // Conditional to determine if 3rd round is necessary. doRound(); } 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:Control may reach end of non void function

I did some searching on the internet and someone suggested writing else { return NULL; } Is this legal/ acceptable? It did get rid of my error.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2172
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-30T02:02:29Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2171
Subject:
Content:You should rewrite your function to avoid using return NULL; it can cause surprising issues. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2173
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-30T02:12:01Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2171
Subject:
Content:Just put some return <proper type> with a comment saying it shouldn't ever execute that code. Like this: int functionA(){ switch(...){ case ...: return ...; case ...: return ...; default: return ...; // No matter what, this switch case should return something. } return 0; // This statement should never execute. }
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2185
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-09-30T04:28:56Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2181
Subject:You're checking if either of the player has more wins. Here, Arya has 1 win and Hodor has 0 wins, so you end the game. Instead, check if either of the player has 2 wins and only then end the game. Otherwise, continue to round 3.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2210
Poster:student
Num Views:12
Type:question
Created:2014-09-30T03:59:50Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:bool isRoundWinner don't know where to go from here
Content:So, i understand that isRoundWinner requires if, else if, else ( for tie?) , but i'm confused when it says i used it within the do round? i don't know how to implement that function within the other.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2211
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-30T05:22:12Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2210
Subject:
Content:I think you're confusing the language used. That is, the difference between calling/using/invoking a function and implementing it. See if this helps: You are not implementing the isRoundWinner function within the doRound function, you are calling/using (see @656) it. So you will write the code to implement isRoundWinner: bool isRoundWinner(char move, char opponent_move) { // code for function here } Then call/use it when implementing (within) doRound: int doRound(string p1_name, string p2_name) { char p1_move; char p2_move; // other code if(isRoundWinner(p1_move, p2_move)) { // code } ... } This is just sample code and needs a lot of work. There are a bunch of ways to form the logic using isRoundWinner within doRound.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2212
Poster:student
Num Views:2
Type:question
Created:2014-09-30T06:23:21Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:getWinCount
Content:Whenever my code goes into a third round, it doesn't print the winner of the game, even though the person wins two rounds: I am using this output sample: ---------------------------------------- EECS 183 Rock-Paper-Scissors ---------------------------------------- Player 1, enter your name: Anna Player 2, enter your name: Kristoff Anna, enter your move: s Kristoff, enter your move: p Anna wins the round! Anna, enter your move: r Kristoff, enter your move: p Kristoff wins the round! Anna, enter your move: r Kristoff, enter your move: s Anna wins the round! Congratulations Anna! You won EECS 183 Rock-Paper-Scissors! Instead of "You won EECS 183 Rock-Paper-Scissors!" it prints "No Winner!" I'm guessing it is my getWinCount not returning the number of times the person wins correctly. How does one go about returning the values for this function?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2213
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-30T06:25:48Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2212
Subject:
Content:Are you running getWinCount() again after the third round? If not, you need to do this to recalculate the values. It is also possible that your logic for setting winner_name is not quite right in the case of a third round. If it's neither of these things, then the problem is most likely in getWinCount().
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2214
Poster:student

Subject:Source code functions and the auto grader (RPS)
Content:Is it alright if we choose not to modify any of the functions given in the original rps.cpp source code, but choose not to use them? I believe the project specs said that we would fail the auto grader if we modified them. I'm wondering if not calling them in our program also causes our program to fail the auto grader. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2217
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-30T14:36:14Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2216
Subject:
Content:You must at least implement them. The autograder tests most of them individuaully. But you could pass if you implement the functions correctly but don't use them. But if you write them, you may as well use them. If you don't use the functions, you would definitely get your style grade reduced.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2223
Poster:student
Num Views:8
Type:question
Created:2014-09-30T15:11:52Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:getMove
Content:So I am in the process of compiling all of my functions into int main() and I can not figure out why I can not get the string of the inserted player names to stay for the getMove function. I have two string variables set to store getName(1) and getName(2) and then I put that variable into my getMove ex: getMove("variable") When I run it, it say variable enter your move rather than the string. I checked the FAQs and I think I am storing it correctly
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2224
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-30T16:33:06Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2223
Subject:
Content:Because when you are calling the function, you are providing it the literal string "variable" and not the variable you are storing the names in. Here's an example of the difference string variable = getName(1); getMove("variable"); // uses the LITERAL string, no the variable getMove(variable); // uses the VARIABLE 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2225
Poster:student
Num Views:13
Type:question
Created:2014-09-30T15:29:31Z
Tags:lecture
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Integer Assignment
Content:I tried posting this yday but I didn't see my post when I checked again... if i set int x = 012. When I print out the value it states that its something very different from 12. Why is that so??
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2226
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-30T16:31:09Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2225
Subject:
Content:When you assign 012 to an int, it reads 012 as a hexadecimal value. You should NOT be placing a zero in front of a number, because we are only using decimal values, not hex.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:RMEs
Content:Hi, I asked a GSI in office hours about deleting the comments given to us in the original cpp document and I was told that it probably did not matter, so I deleted all of the comments, including the RMEs for the given functions. (I know now that I probably should have left them in.) I turned the project in before Monday in order to get the extra credit. In the style guide it says, "Each function created by the student (except main) should have an RME comment above." Since I did not create any of the functions that I removed the RMEs for, will I be penalized in my style grade? If so, will that penalty outweigh the extra points I earned for turning the project in two days early? Sorry for the wordy question. Thanks!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2236
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-30T16:29:37Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2235
Subject:
Content:No, you will not lose points for not having RMEs for the functions we provide to you. You are required to provide RMEs for functions you write on your own that we do not provide.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Tags:logistics, project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Do all if-statements need a return?
Content:So I'm rewriting my getWinCount function, and I have a series of if-statements (no elses involved). Do I need a return if all I'm doing is incrementing a variable in the statement, since it's not a function?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2243
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-30T20:05:25Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2242
Subject:
Content:There's no real connection between ifs and returns, necessarily. Every function always needs to return something, but this isn't really directly related to ifs. That being said you need to make sure that every branch of an if-else does return something, but this doesn't mean the returns have to be inside of the branches themselves.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2252
Poster:student
Num Views:9
Type:question
Created:2014-09-30T21:36:45Z
Tags:codelab
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:11128
Content:I don't get why we are using && and not || when the prompt says Y' or 'y' or 'N' or 'n'
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2253
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-09-30T22:17:28Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2252
Subject:
Content:You need to exit the loop if any of the input is 'Y' 'y' 'N' or 'n'. Therefore, if it is not equal to any of those values, the loop keeps going. When all cases return true for not being equal to those chars, the loop continues.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2256
Poster:student
Num Views:10
Type:question
Created:2014-09-30T22:53:02Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:getWinCount and announceWinner
Content:I am pretty sure I have all of my code written correctly but I am a little confused on how to add getWinCount and announceWinner into my int main function. Everything runs smoothly up until this point. I am not sure how I need to go about initializing player_num for the function part of getWinCount. I have each round winner initialized to the doRound function.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2257
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-09-30T23:40:29Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2256
Subject:
Content:You should have the winners of each round stored in variables. player_num is 1 (signifying player 1) or player_num is 2 (signifying player 2). So you might call it like: getWinCount(1, round1, round2, round3). This would return the total number of times player 1 won given the parameters round1, round2, and round3 (each representing the winner of the respective round). In your main function you need to use this to determine who won the game. After all, isn't that what we care about? :) If you still have questions, try searching Piazza and viewing @656. Lots of questions have been asked about getWinCount.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2281
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-01T01:54:12Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2280
Subject:
Content:Your output doesn't appear to the be the same as the expected output. In the expected output, the results are draw, p1 win, p2 win, which should be a draw because p1 and p2 have equal wins. in your output, the results are draw, p1 win, draw. In this case, p1 should win because they have more wins.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Endorsements:0
Response To:2280
Subject:I think you are incorrectly determining a winner if all 3 rounds are played. You should be calling the getWinCount function to determine the number of wins for both players. if one win count is higher than the other, they should win, otherwise, it should be a draw.

Piazza Post:2322

Response To:-1
Subject:Late Days
Content:If I turn in my project2 a day late (Thursday) and use a late day, does it count as if I had used two late days if I turn both the debugit.txt and rps.cpp late or is it still only one day. Also if I use a late day, is it due the next day at 6pm or at midnight?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2323
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-01T12:53:09Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2322
Subject:
Content:We only count by days, we don't count by the number of submissions or project parts you need to submit for a day. So that means submitting both parts on Thursday would use only 1 late day. Your project is subject to the normal rules (officially due at 6pm, unofficially at 11:59:59pm)

Piazza Post:2327
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-01T12:58:31Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2326
Subject:
Content:I just want to make sure I understand your question. When I read this question I'm reading "I know we have x submits per day that give us feedback and a score, but for the unlimited submissions after our feedback, do we still get a score?" If that is not the correct question, please correct me in a follow up. Now, if that IS the question, the answer is no. A blind submit is just like it sounds, blind. You see nothing about how the submission went. No score, no feedback, nothing. The autograder will simply tell you whether or not it accepted the submission

Piazza Post:2331
Poster:student
Num Views:39
Type:question
Created:2014-10-01T14:59:42Z
Tags:codelab
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:CodeLab 11135 and 11138
Content:35: Write a loop that reads positive <link> integers from standard input and that terminates when it reads an <link> integer that is not positive. After the <link> loop terminates , it prints out the <link> sum of all the even <link> integers read, the <link> sum of all the odd <link> integers read, a count of the number of even <link> integers read, and a count of the number of odd <link> integers read, all separated by exactly one space. <link> Declare any <link> variables that are needed. 38: Consider this data sequence: "3 11 5 5 5 2 4 6 6 7 3 -8". Any <link> value that is the same as the immediately preceding <link> value is considered a CONSECUTIVE DUPLICATE. In this example, there are three such consecutive duplicates: the 2nd and 3rd 5s and the second 6. Note that the last 3 is not a consecutive duplicate because it was preceded by a 7. Write some code that uses a loop to read such a sequence of non-negative <link> integers , terminated by a negative number. When the code exits the loop it should print the number of consecutive duplicates encountered. In the above case, that <link> value would be 3. The debugger in CodeLab is claiming that my while loop goes into an infinite loop for both of these answers. I've tried both of the exact same code in visual studio and my program works exactly as it should! I think the error comes in while using "cin" in the while loop. Is there a trick to using "cin" in CodeLab that I am unaware of? Or is the problem somewhere else?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2332
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-01T15:53:15Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2331
Subject:
Content:Think about what condition it is you want to stop at. if you just say while (cin >> something) then as long as anything that matches the type of something gets entered, the loop will continue. We want to end depending on what the value of something is, which will require a different condition.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2333
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-10-01T23:15:29Z
Tags:

Piazza Post:2335
Poster:student
Num Views:8
Type:question
Created:2014-10-01T15:05:45Z
Tags:project2
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:repeating functions
Content:My getMove function keeps repeating itself twice. I'm not sure what to do. i think I may have accidentally declared it twice. Once in the main and then again in the doRound function. In the doRound function, I assigned the getMove function to variables I created, char p1Move and p2Move. I think I could just use my getMove function directly as a parameter for the doRound function, but I tried that and it just repeats itself more. Could use the help
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2336
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-01T15:32:11Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2335
Subject:
Content:You are right that you should not be calling the function twice. When you call doRound() from inside main(), all of the code inside doRound() will be run. This includes the call you have to getMove(). So, you don't need to also call getMove() from main() since it's already going to happen when you call doRound().
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:Autograder Test 21 Expected Output Question
Content:I have a question regarding the expected output for test 21. The expected output inputs values into the program and returns with one victory for player 2 and two draws. The output then goes on to state that player 2 has won the game even though player 2 has not won 2 rounds. Could this be a bug in the system? Shouldn't the entire game return with "No Winner!"? What does this tell me about how the autograder is testing my code? Here is the expected output for test 21: ============================= Expected Output ============================= ---------------------------------------- EECS 183 Rock-Paper-Scissors ---------------------------------------- Player 1, enter your name: Player 2, enter your name: Player 1, enter your move: Player 2, enter your move: Player 2 wins the round! Player 1, enter your move: Player 2, enter your move: This round is a draw! Player 1, enter your move: ERROR: Illegal move given, using default Player 2, enter your move: This round is a draw! Congratulations Player 2! You won EECS 183 Rock-Paper-Scissors! 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2356
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-01T18:16:02Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2355
Subject:
Content:If p2 wins 1/3 games, and p1 wins 0/3 games, then p2 has won more rounds than p1. p2 wins.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2379

Response To:-1
Subject:Local function definitions are illegal? Project 2
Content:For quite a few of my functions, i get an error message saying "local function definitions are illegal", but I'm 99% sure they are right. I have the right brackets in the right places, all my semi-colons, etc. and I'm working off of visual studios. Can anyone help?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2380
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-01T21:44:11Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2379
Subject:
Content:This is usually the result of a missing curly brace and/or trying to define your functions inside the scope of another function. Make sure you aren't defining functions inside of functions and double check your curly braces. On VS I believe the hotkey Ctrl+K followed by Ctrl+D will auto format the document and this can help with the curly braces
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2402
Poster:student
Num Views:20
Type:question
Created:2014-10-02T00:26:53Z
Tags:zyante
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Confuse about this sentence on Zybook
Content:'A common error is to accidentally create an infinite loop due to assuming equality will be reached.' What's this mean?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2403
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-02T01:03:10Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2402
Subject:
Content:It's a loop where the condition always evaluates to true and so the loop never stops. For example, consider int i = 100; while (i != 0) { cout << "hi there!" << endl; i -= 3; } 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
