Piazza Post:2422
Poster:student
Num Views:6
Type:question
Created:2014-10-02T04:48:46Z
Tags:codelab
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:11138, 11139, 11140
Content:I am confused by exercises 11138, 11139, 11140. I am not sure how to determine whether there is a consecutive duplicate/how many consecutive duplicates there are in the sequence of numbers read in. Also, I'm not sure how to terminate the loop because I'm not sure what is supposed to be read in. I thought it would have something to do with the sequence terminating in a negative integer, but I don't know how to make that a condition if the sequence is read in as one input, because even when there is a negative number at the end of the sequence, the sequence itself will still be nonnegative. All of the exercises are similar to this one: Consider this data sequence: "3 11 5 5 5 2 4 6 6 7 3 -8". Any <link> value that is the same as the immediately preceding <link> value is considered a CONSECUTIVE DUPLICATE. In this example, there are three such consecutive duplicates: the 2nd and 3rd 5s and the second 6. Note that the last 3 is not a consecutive duplicate because it was preceded by a 7. Write some code that uses a loop to read such a sequence of non-negative <link> integers , terminated by a negative number. When the code exits the loop it should print the number of consecutive duplicates encountered. In the above case, that <link> value would be 3. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2423
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-02T05:37:50Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2422
Subject:
Content:See @758 for how to write the loop. As far as determining consecutive duplicates, try to think about how you would accomplish the same problem as a person (eg. only seeing one number at a time). This is a challenging problem and may require some experimentation to get right.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2432
Poster:instructor
Num Views:136
Type:question
Created:2014-10-02T12:23:08Z
Tags:project3
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Bad data checking
Content:"It is the responsibility of the programming calling the function to guarantee that the Requires clause is adhered to." By this, does it mean we don't need to check bad input in asciiart.cpp? And we just need to make sure we don't write an invalid call in test1.cpp ? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2433
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-02T14:37:24Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2432
Subject:
Content:This means in asciiart.cpp, you may assume that all calls of your functions will follow the requires clause of the RME. You do not need to check in your code, and we won't write any test cases that check arguments against the requires clause. It also means in test1.cpp all your calls follow the RMEs. If they don't, the program will fail the autograder.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2445
Poster:student
Num Views:2
Type:question
Created:2014-10-02T16:37:23Z
Tags:project3
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Second Rectangle function
Content:Why does the second rectangle function have examples that are identical to the first one? Is the second rectangle supposed to be indented in by the third parameter?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2446
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-02T16:44:10Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2445
Subject:
Content:The second printRectangle() function takes three parameters: no of rows, no of columns, and an offset. The offset parameter specifies how many spaces from the left margin the rectangle should be printed. The first printRectangle() function takes only two parameters: no of rows, and no of columns.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2465

Num Views:12
Type:question
Created:2014-10-02T19:22:30Z
Tags:project3
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Is there a limit to the number of test cases we can utilize in test1.cpp?
Content:Since there seems to be no specific limit, can we put as many test cases as we feel is necessary for each function? Also, is test1.cpp purely the following; no endl's or anything?: #include <iostream> #include <string> #include "asciiart.h" using namespace std; int main(){ function1(...); function1(...); function2(...); function2(...); // etc.? } Or can we separate our test cases with cout << endl; so that it's easier to distinguish the outputs of each test case?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2466
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-02T19:30:20Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2465
Subject:
Content:There is no limit to the number of function calls, so you should make as many function calls as possible to full test the functionality of your functions (as well as the autograder's tests). The autograder may have a specific time limit on how long it will let test1.cpp run until it forces it to end, but you would (most likely) need thousands and thousands of function calls to reach this time limit. and please put in "endl's" such that you can read your output and tell if you have the output you expected the autograder doesn't care, but you will and the staff will also love it if your output is readable
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2467

Content:Yes, you may define your own helper functions for the project (assuming you define the given/required functions as well). If you do, be sure to provide your own RMEs for those functions.

Piazza Post:2489

Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Positive proper divisor of 1
Content:Does 1 have positive proper divisor?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2490
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-03T00:59:53Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2489
Subject:
Content:A positive proper divisor is a positive divisor of n excluding n itself. So no, 1 does not have proper divisors.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2493
Poster:student
Num Views:4
Type:question
Created:2014-10-03T00:42:18Z
Tags:other
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Discussion Slide Question
Content:I was looking over discussion slides and I wanted to know what the reasoning for this answer was. I thought that if you used the assignment operator it would always return true right? <image> 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2494
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-03T00:57:36Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2493
Subject:
Content:The result of assignment is the value that's assigned. x = 0 returns 0, x = 2 returns 2, x = -1 returns -1. 0 is synonymous to false, so the statement in else is evaluated.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:printStringInBox
Content:for printStringInBox function, is it possible that there are some spaces at the end of the string? (like: "string ") If so, should there be one space between * and the last letter in the string or the last space in the string?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2515
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-03T15:00:40Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2514
Subject:
Content:You do not need to remove extra whitespace, so if the string were "string ", you'd need to print *********** * string * ***********

Response To:2533
Subject: Also with regards to output differences. A comment near the top of asciiart.h says that (no spaces at the end of lines and blank lines are printed by test1.cpp) For every function The last line should end with an 'endl'. No blank lines should be printed at the beginning nor at the end. However, the RMEs for printRectangle both say "Note: the blank lines are printed by test1.cpp and there are no spaces at the end of lines." Does that mean the functions printRectangle should not end with an endl? Also, does this note apply to the other print Functions or only printRectangle? 
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2536
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-10-03T19:10:27Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2533
Subject:The last character printed by printRectangle should indeed be a newline character, but don't print an extra blank line. In other words, after printRectangle prints a rectangle, the cursor should move to the next line.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:Xcode Build Error

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2545
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-10-03T21:00:16Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2544
Subject:
Content:I may try a few things. 1) Make sure main() is in test1.cpp 2) Sometimes if you declare a function but don't define it, xcode likes to scream, so try defining them in the simplest sense (voids are okay, but make sure bools return either true or false even if they do nothing) 3) It also likes to do this if you are passing the wrong types of variables to formulas, so if you've started writing any code, make sure all the passed variables are of the right kind 4) try again and see if you get the same results.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2546
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer

Endorsements:0
Response To:2544

Content:Also make sure that asciiart.h, asciiart.cpp and test1.cpp are all in the same folder on your computer.

Response To:-1
Subject:Creating project 3 file
Content:How do you create the file for Project 3 on Xcode? I created a new project on Xcode and added the aciiart.h file to the project. When I typed #include "asciiart.h" at the top of asciiart.cpp I got a complier error saying 'asciiart.h' file not found.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2564
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-03T22:20:23Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2563
Subject:
Content:When you add asciiart.h to your Xcode project, be sure to that Destination: Copy items if needed is selected. Then create a new file, saving it to your project folder (you should see a copy of asciiart.h there too), and call it asciiart.cpp. Inside of it, be sure to #include "asciiart.h". Finally, create test1.cpp and also #include "asciiart.h". test1.cpp should be the only file with a main function.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2586
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None

Created:2014-10-04T04:34:16Z

Endorsements:0
Response To:2585
Subject:
Content:I would suggest you start with paper and pencil. Draw out the triangles and think about how many spaces and how many *'s it takes for he triangle. You will discover the algorithm it takes. Piazza Post:2610

Response To:2607
Subject:Instead of looking if the number you print is start, try to keep track of whether you've printed a number at all. If you haven't printed any numbers, that means you're printing the first number and thus do not need to print the comma.

Piazza Post:2614
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-04T23:54:39Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2613
Subject:
Content:If you see the "Attach" message it basically means that you've opened a file rather than opening a project/solution. VisualStudio doesn't know how to run a single file, it only knows how to run an entire solution. I believe that "Attach" is for connecting the file to another project, but I'm a lifelong Mac user so I really don't know and wouldn't recommend using this for anything besides a personal experiment.

Response To:-1
Subject:Creating Own Functions
Content:Are we allowed to create our own functions in asciiart.cpp that are not prototyped in asciiart.h? I want to make a function that will make my code for isMersennePrime much simpler. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2618
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-04T23:57:37Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2617
Subject:
Content:You may, but keep in mind that you are not submitting a .h file, only a .cpp. This means you would need to put the function headers for custom functions in the .cpp file, as we did for projects 1 and 2. Also be aware that the Autograder tests the functions we distributed, so if you are using your custom function inside of isMersennePrime then that's fine, but the Autograder will run whatever code you have in the definition of isMersennePrime.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2623
Poster:student
Num Views:14
Type:question
Created:2014-10-04T21:39:20Z
Tags:project3
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Variable style
Content:In project three my partner and I have been using variables like i and j in the functions like the examples we have seen in class like for (i = 0; i < n; ++i) but we are using a lot of the same letters in different functions is this considered bad style? should our variables be something different than just letters?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2624
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-10-04T21:54:43Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2623
Subject:
Content:It's not a bad style. i, j, k are conventional variables for loops. Since their scopes are limited within their own functions, as long as you don't name global variables for i, j, k, it won't cause any trouble or confusion. However, if you constantly change the loop variable(for example, from a to z), that's when whoever reads your code might be confused.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2625
Poster:student
Num Views:8
Type:question
Created:2014-10-04T21:57:52Z

Piazza Post:2627
Poster:student
Num Views:29
Type:question
Created:2014-10-04T22:05:30Z
Tags:codelab
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:why cin after while statement?
Content:I have a question about codeLab , which the answer should be like this: Write a loop that reads <link> strings from standard input where the <link> string is either "duck" or "goose". The <link> loop terminates when "goose" is read in. After the loop, your code should print out the number of "duck" <link> strings that were read. string readIn="duck"; int i = 0; while ((readIn == "duck")||(readIn == "goose")) { cin >> readIn; if (readIn == "goose") { break; } else { i++; } } cout << i; in the answer, if I put cin >> readIn in front of while loop, it would be wrong. Why is that?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2628
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-10-04T23:25:57Z
Tags:
Endorsements:3
Response To:2627
Subject:
Content:Suppose you put cin>> readIn in front of the while loop. If you input goose, while loop executes because the statement is true. And it will break out when it executes to if(readin == "goose"). And then output 0; However, if you input duck, the while statement is always true, which will lead to an infinite loop and "i" will keep incrementing because readIn is never updated. Also, if you input anything besides goose and duck, while loop will not execute so the program will output 0, just like in the first case. You can always test it in a compiler. For the record, 183 doesn't encourage students to use "break;" unless it's in switch statement.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2629
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-05T22:47:56Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2627
Subject:
Content:To elaborate on the last sentence: you will lose style points if you use a "break;" outside of a switch statement. Do not use them; come up with a way to end the loop in the condition instead.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2630
Poster:student
Num Views:21
Type:question
Created:2014-10-04T22:08:51Z
Tags:lecture
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:why is that 1.1 + 2.2 != 3.3?
Content:in the lecture last week, a clicker question mentioned that 1.1+ 2.2 != 3.3 in float point section. The explanations are since 1.1 and 2.2 are all float points, so there would be some things left after 3.3. How exactly does 1.1+ 2.2 result in?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2631
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-05T00:00:48Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:2630
Subject:
Content:It's because of the way that the computer represents decimals. The details aren't terrifically important, but the issue is basically that the computer uses a value extremely close to but not exactly 1.1 and 2.2 As we saw in the iClicker question, the value might be something like 1.10000000001. More details of this are given in EECS370. For now it's just important to know that checking doubles for equality is not something that will always work.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2632
Poster:student
Num Views:12
Type:question
Created:2014-10-04T22:29:09Z
Tags:zyante
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:do-while loop question
Content:I was reading about do-while loops and practice questions concerning them, and I had a question about how a do-while loop is read in a program. Is it essentially telling the program to completely disregard what's in the while conditions until the loop executes at least once?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2633
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-05T00:01:25Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2632
Subject:
Content:Yes. The semantics are equivalent to "do this and then continue doing it if this condition is true".
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2638
Poster:student
Num Views:7
Type:question
Created:2014-10-05T01:52:59Z
Tags:project3
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Stubbed Failed to Build
Content:I know this question has been asked before on project 2, but I'm trying to submit every time I implement a new function. When I submit the asciiart.cpp file with just the first function implemented, it says "undefined reference to" and lists all the other functions. So I tried to delete all the other function prototypes besides the first one from the header file, and submitted it again. However, I'm still getting the same message. How can I change my cpp file so that it no longer shows this error? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2639
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-05T01:57:13Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:2638
Subject:
Content:The problem is that the definitions for each function do need to exist. Part of this is that any function that returns an integer needs to return an integer. To solve this, I insert statements like return 0; and return false; just so that the file will compile. As an example: bool isPrime(int n){ return false; } You can obviously change it later, but this is the solution to your problem. As far as submitting every time you finish a function, that's ok but there's really no reason not to just test on your machine. These functions are pretty easy to verify. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Poster:student

SO. I went back, changed the function name in the declaration, definition, and calls, but now my compiler fails and states "error C2660: 'printRectangle' does not take 3 arguments". I submitted the test1.cpp file to the autograder anyway and it didn't return any related errors (gave me a 3/10 so far), but what is going on???
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2669
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-10-09T15:46:19Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2660
Subject:Double check and make sure you changed the name of the function in both the .cpp and .h files in your project (and double check they are spelled correctly, as this is a common error as well). The reason the compiler can tell the difference between printRectanlge(int rows, int cols) and printRectangle(int row, int cols, int offset), is because the number of parameters are different (even thought they have the same name). This is called "function overloading," which basically means we're using the same function name but they have different parameter lists. It's sort of like when families pass down a name to each generation. I'm William John Wolfington V while my dad is William John Wolfington IV: we both have the exact same name, but we are uniquely identified by the IV and V of our names (you can think of those as parameters).
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2673
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-05T22:11:07Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2672
Subject:
Content:The non-deterministic output means that with multiple runs of a correct set of functions, you are getting differing outputs. This can happen for numerous reasons. Uninitialized variables or using any kind of random number generator will cause this issue, so make sure your test suite doesn't have these issues.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2688
Poster:instructor
Num Views:27
Type:note
Created:2014-10-05T22:53:09Z
Tags:pin, project3
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Stubbing Functions
Content:Before you submit to the autograder, make sure all of the functions are either written or at least stubbed! This is what we mean by stubbing. If we have a function void foo(int l, int w); Stubbing it would look like this: void foo(int l, int w) { } This way, when the compiler looks for an implementation, it finds one (even though it doesn't do anything). Stubbing a function with a return type would look like this: int foo(int l, int w) { return 0; } Match your what you return (like an int 0 or a char 'a') to the return type of the function. #pin 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2689
Poster:student

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2722
Poster:student
Num Views:15
Type:question
Created:2014-10-06T01:52:34Z
Tags:logistics, project3
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Declaring Variables in ForLoops
Content:So when we wrote functions with variables in the past it would look something like this: myFunction() { int thisVariable; int thatVariable; // Code } However, I noticed that some people in for loops write things like: for( int thisVariable = 7; ... ; ...) where they declare AND define a variable within the for loop.... Is that ok? is it just a style thing? the code seems to run fine but I don't know what I should be doing in that respect... Thank you! 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2723
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-06T01:53:29Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2722
Subject:
Content:It's definitely a good thing to do. However, a variable declared inside a loop will no longer exist outside the loop. Loops get their own scope. EDIT: Another thing to note is that a variable declared in a loop only exists for that iteration of the loop. Hence, these all mean different things: int i = 0; for(i; i < 10; i++); for(int i = 0; i < 10; i++); for(int j = 0; j < 10; j++){ int i = 0; i++; } In the first, you could access the value of i after the loop -- it lives across all iterations of the loop. In the second, i's scope is restricted to the loop, but the same i lives across all iterations. However, in the third, you are declaring and incrementing a different i every time the loop executes for one j.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2733
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None

Created:2014-10-06T03:34:05Z

Endorsements:0
Response To:2731
Subject:
Content:NO it is NOT the functions job to guarantee the Requires. It is the calling programs job to make sure they don't violate the requires. The functions get to assume what is stated in the requires to be true

Subject:sumProperDivisors

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2751
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-10-06T16:13:02Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:2750
Subject:
Content:No, it needs to be int because the function returns something (a sum) that will be used in later functions. Void functions do not return any values, so it can not be void.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2752
Poster:student
Num Views:8
Type:question
Created:2014-10-06T16:50:50Z
Tags:project3
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Iterate through a string
Content:How do you iterate through a string to check if the string contains control characters?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2753
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-06T18:00:24Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2752
Subject:
Content:It's in the requires clause, so you may assume that it doesn't have any control characters. But if you wanted to access individual characters of a string str (no need to do this in project 3), you would do str[0] to get the first character, str[1] to get the second character, etc.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:2763

Piazza Post:2764
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-06T19:35:59Z
Tags:
Endorsements:4
Response To:2763
Subject:
Content:Ah yes, linker errors! So, it says there's a duplicate symbol- a lot of the time this means that you have two implementations for the same function in your files. Often, this is the function main(). Check that first and make sure you don't have two main functions in your project!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:Autograder for mersenne primes

Subject:Own Functions

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2795
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-06T22:48:17Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2794
Subject:
Content:You don't have to create your own functions, but I'd recommend you do. Whenever your code gets repetitive and you start copying and pasting code, you know there's something you could be doing better. There are a few functions in project 3 that require you to do the same thing. Rather than duplicating code, I suggest you use functions.

Subject:What is the max run time allowed for project 3?

Piazza Post:2804
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-06T23:26:06Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2803
Subject:
Content:I don't think we limit the amount of output, but we do stop running your code after about 30 seconds. Anyway, you should not be outputting 1000 lines in your test cases, since this will not help you detect bugs. (How long will it take you to count the number of stars to make sure that you correctly printed a triangle?)

Piazza Post:2830
Poster:student
Num Views:56
Type:question
Created:2014-10-07T03:43:45Z
Tags:project3
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:spacing
Content:For almost every function we have using asterisks, there is an extra line of spaces printed at the bottom, thus failing the autograder. We tried fixing it, but in order to do so it would also alter the number of rows of asterisks we have (which we don't want). Anyone have a suggestion? I'm referring to pointisoscelesdown, printrighttriangle, etc.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2831
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-07T04:00:52Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2830
Subject:
Content:In printRightWithSpaces, you print a space after each star. In printIsoscelesPointingDown, you print spaces after each newline character, including after the very last row of stars. Instead, you should be printing spaces before printing the row of stars.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Response To:2842

Subject:str.length( ) type

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2848
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-07T16:22:32Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2847
Subject:
Content:str.length() returns an unsigned int and gives you the length of the entire string (in other words, the number of characters in the string).
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Response To:-1
Subject:Do we need to include RMEs for the test functions?
Content:It is really confusing that in the lecture, the ppt showed an example test1.cpp that define all the test functions like: void test_printRectangle() {...} then print test functions into main However, during the tutoring,the test1.cpp is just like int main{ printRetangle (3, 1); ... } Which one is the true test1.cpp the autograder wants? Also I wonder whether we still need something like for loops in test1.cpp Because someone told me the critical values should be defined but I still think what has already in the asciiart.h do not need to be defined again. Thanks
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2859
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-07T18:03:54Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2858
Subject:
Content:The reason you see two different ways of doing test1.cpp is because it's two different logical ways to do it. Option 1 is the test functions void testPrintRectangle() { printRectangle(2,3); // more tests here } int main() { testPrintRectangle(); } The reason this is preferred is because it makes the organization of which functions are being tests much easier. The other option is to call each function individually. Either option is completely fine, you will not be marked down for your choice in this case :)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2860
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-10-07T18:11:27Z

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2861
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-10-07T19:59:07Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2858
Subject:The point of test1.cpp is for you to make sure your functions work correctly in every test case. The only way to know is to call the function multiple times, using different input to test different cases. This is the exact same idea as the CodeLab questions for testmax() and testInOrder(), but you do not need if statements. You only need cout statements and function calls.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2862
Poster:student
Num Views:131
Type:question
Created:2014-10-07T17:42:30Z
Tags:project3
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:printPrimes commas
Content:I'm having a problem in which the list of primes that comes back has a comma attached to the last value. How can I prevent this?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2863
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-07T17:55:16Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2862
Subject:
Content:When you're printing primes, instead of printing the number first, and then a comma, try printing a comma first, and then the number: cout << ", " << number; Note that this will not work for the first prime. For that one, you'll need to write some if-else logic that takes care of first vs. non-first cases.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-07T18:54:53Z

Endorsements:1
Response To:2871
Subject:
Content:It actually depends on the compiler. Some of them are smart enough to prevent it, some of them process it as a runtime error, and some of them don't notice at all.

Response To:2895

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2898
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-10-08T02:38:28Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2895
Subject:if you test with values that violate the required clauses you will get an assertion error and your score will be a 0 Remember "Required" means -- it is the calling programs job to guarantee that the "Required" will not be violated. The function can assume that all is good.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Poster:student

Created:2014-10-08T15:48:18Z

Piazza Post:2950
Poster:student
Num Views:19
Type:question
Created:2014-10-08T04:36:42Z
Tags:project3
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Linker Command Fail with Exit Code 1
Content:Does anyone know how to solve this?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2951
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-08T04:55:53Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2950
Subject:
Content:Make sure that you only have one main function in your program (if you have a main() in test1.cpp and in asciiart.cpp, your program won't compile). Also check to see that all three files (asciiart.h, asciiart.cpp, and test1.cpp) are stored in the same folder on your computer. Sometimes if you drag and drop files into Xcode or Virtual Studio, they do not end up stored in the same folder so you get linking errors. Also, make sure you have #include "asciiart.h" at the top of both your test1.cpp and asciiart.cpp. Also, see <link> Stubbing Functions
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Poster:student

Piazza Post:2968
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-08T14:06:10Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2967
Subject:
Content:swap() is not included in <cmath>, but in <string>. <link> http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/string/string/swap-free/ Depending on what you want to swap (numbers vs strings), you might need to write your own function.

Content:You'll do the final project in teams. So be assured that you'll not appear at the showcase by yourself. There will be your team members as well. In general, it can be a game that you design, some data mining challenge problem you solve, or problems related to hardware, graphics, web design, and big data. We're working on the specs, and you'll hear from us very soon.

Piazza Post:2986
Poster:instructor
Num Views:253
Type:note
Created:2014-10-08T18:13:18Z
Tags:no_history, project3
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:FAQs on Project 3
Content:We had a few questions on Project 3 that were asked very frequently: 1. Comma in printPrimes Many of you got your printPrimes output look like this: 3, 5, 7, 11, The issue here is with grouping. Instead of grouping your output like this (spacing added for clarity): 3, 5, 7, 11, Consider grouping your output like this: 3 , 5 , 7 , 11 2. printIsosceles and nested loops in general: * Try making a table. This is always a good strategy when you have nested loops *** You can use to table to figure out what your loops conditions should be. ***** The following table is an example for printIsosceles(3) nrow_numberspaces_neededstars_needed302131133205 Now try to derive an equation for spaces_needed and stars_needed based on n. 3. What's a Mersenne prime? A Mersenne prime is a prime number of the form $$2^n - 1$$, where $$n$$ is another prime. So, $$7$$ is a Mersenne prime because $$7 = 2^3 - 1$$ and $$3$$ is also a prime number. 4. Getting the project set up/compiler errors from the autograder due to stubbing For stubbing, please check out the <link> project tutorial (around 45 minutes). 5. Extra or missing endlines in Autograder feedback Make sure you have one endl at the end of all asciiart functions - as specified. No more and no less. 6. The middle row of stars in printArrow The <link> tutorial suggests you break down printArrow into three pieces, the upper triangle, lower triangle, and the middle. If you are struggle with this, consider further breaking the middle down into two pieces - the *'s that appear instead of spaces and the rest of the *'s in that line. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:What to include in test1.cpp
Content:My partner and I aren't sure what we need to test in our int main() for test1.cpp. I assumed that all of the sample code listed in the project description for each function should be tested such as: printRectangle(3,2); cout << endl; printRectangle(1,3); so I have included that for each function, but from reading some of the other piazza posts and the project description, it seems that I should include as many possible scenarios for each function as possible so that I can prove my code works correctly for every case. Is this a correct assumption? If so, how thorough should I be with my tests? Basically just the edge cases for each function, then one or two within the range?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:2990
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-08T19:35:15Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:2989
Subject:
Content:The strategy you've proposed sounds good to me. Basically you want to cover all the possible scenarios that you think could be meaningfully different from each other. This basically means edge cases.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3017
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-09T00:30:25Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3016
Subject:
Content:If you received 10/10, that is your score for the testing portion, so yes it is full credit. In real life, when you're testing, you want to expose as many bugs as possible, so it would be to your benefit if you tried to find all 18.

Response To:-1
Subject:what to add in .cpp if creating own functions
Content:We created a swap function and wrote the RME for it, but since we only submit the .cpp file, how do we show the RME? Do we put the function headers for custom functions in the .cpp file? Do we copy and paste everything from the header file to the .cpp file? But I saw that in the project description, the .cpp file only includes the definition of functions. How do we do this? I am a little confused.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3021
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-09T01:20:26Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3020
Subject:
Content:You should not modify asciiart.h. Since the autograder uses the given version of asciiart.h, if you make changes then it is likely that the program will not compile when you submit. Any extra functions you write, therefore, should have both their definition and RME in asciiart.cpp. Note: This means you will not be able to specifically test any extra functions you write in the test1.cpp that you turn in to the autograder.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3022

Piazza Post:3030
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-10-09T04:29:38Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3029
Subject:
Content:Common places to make mistakes on printPrimes is when the start is bigger than the end and when you start and end at the same number. Additionally, the auto grader gives you an idea of what test cases it's running. So you could just try all those scenarios.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3031
Poster:student
Num Views:5
Type:question
Created:2014-10-09T02:29:39Z
Tags:project3

Piazza Post:3050

Response To:-1
Subject:Test Suite Autograder Failed
Content:In our first submit to the test suite autograder, our program did not run because of an error. We cannot figure out what is causing this. Our printRectangle() function runs perfectly in our xcode, and also passes the asciiart.cpp autograder test. Could it be because we are testing negative test values to check if it meets the "requires:" statement? Should we be testing negative number cases? Below it the output we received: <image> 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3051
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-09T05:09:39Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3050
Subject:
Content:You should not be testing cases that do not obey the requires clause of the function.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3052
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-10-09T05:10:09Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3050
Subject:
Content: I was just reading the instructions and saw this... "Therefore, the call print_rectangle(-1, 5); // not a valid call is not valid since it violates the Requires clause. The Requires clause means that this MUST be true when the function is called. It is not the responsibility of the function to check. It is the responsibility of the programming calling the function to guarantee that the Requires clause is adhered to. And if you do this and submit this code to the autograder, you will get a 0. The feedback will state you violated the &#8220;assertion&#8221;. The autograder is written to make absolutely sure you adhere to those Requires clauses. When you submit test1.cpp, we will compile and run it with our correct implementation of asciiart.cpp and with our buggy implementation of asciiart.cpp, so as to generate two different outputs. We&#8217;ll then compare two outputs. If there is any difference, you&#8217;ve successfully exposed a bug! The autograder does not go into the details of what the difference is, it only sees if there exists a difference." According to the part in bold, you shouldn't be testing negative values. 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3053
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup

Piazza Post:3077
Poster:student

Created:2014-10-09T18:59:46Z
Tags:other
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:One RME for similar functions?
Content:Can we use one RME that is common to multiple versions of a function? For example: /** Requires: Parameters should be values that shows the *** values being used for a test case. *** Modifies: Nothing. *** Effects: Creates a divider to separate test cases from each other. *** *** Example: printDivider(); *** cout << "Test Case 1" << endl; *** printDivider("abc"); *** cout << "Test Case 2" << endl; *** printDivider(1,5); *** cout << "Test Case 3" << endl; *** printDivider(); *** *** Output: ------- --- ------- *** Test Case 1 *** ------- abc ------- *** Test Case 2 *** ------- 1 - 5 ------- *** Test Case 3 *** ------- --- ------- **/ void printDivider(); void printDivider(int); void printDivider(double); void printDivider(int, int); void printDivider(double, double); void printDivider(string); Currently the style grader accepts this form.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3078
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-09T20:00:59Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3077
Subject:
Content:That'd be a fine way to do things.

Piazza Post:3083
Poster:student
Num Views:43
Type:question
Created:2014-10-09T22:58:23Z
Tags:project3
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Mersenne prime equation and magic numbers.
Content:If you had code that read " var = pow(2.0, var) - 1 " would the 2.0 and the 1 be considered magic numbers? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3084
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-09T23:40:26Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3083
Subject:
Content:No, because this is part of a mathematical formula. Magic numbers are price tags, conversion rates, exchange rates, etc. These are values that are subject to change, but on a longer timescale. Mathematical formulas - on the other hand - are good, unless they involve some numbers such as PI. Numbers such as PI and "e" should be declared as const. Otherwise they'll be magic numbers.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3085
Poster:student
Num Views:7
Type:question
Created:2014-10-09T23:06:04Z

(2^n means 2 to the nth power.) Example: printMersennePrimes(1, 50); 3 7 31 */ Shouldn't the output of the example be: 3 7 15 31 ?? Since 2^4 - 1 = 15.

Piazza Post:3096
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-10-10T01:56:35Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3095
Subject:We don't want an obvious answer. We just need an understanding of why the Autograder has an extra space. There is no obvious way to tell how many triangles the Autograder will test, therefore we cannot create a conditional that explicitly adds an extra space after the second to last triangle. We checked our endls and the number we used inside of our loops. The top triangles are correctly spaced, however, if we change the endls to correct the last one, the first ones are then incorrect.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Poster:instructor

Piazza Post:3110
Poster:student
Num Views:3
Type:question
Created:2014-10-10T01:20:41Z
Tags:project3
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:sumProperDivisors(n) when n is prime
Content:If n is prime, it has no proper divisors. In this case, should sumProperDivisors(n) return 0? EDIT: I realized that sumProperDivisors(n) includes 1, so in this case it would return 1. I'll leave this up for anyone else that was wondering the same thing.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3111
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-10-10T01:23:24Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3110
Subject:
Content:"A positive proper divisor is a positive divisor of n excluding n itself." So if you have a prime number, 7, the only divisors it has are 1 and 7. Then, just add all the divisors the number has that aren't the actual number itself. Edit: Be sure that you know n is not included in the final sum.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:3116
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-10T01:43:07Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3114
Subject:
Content:You do need to print if string has spaces. The Requires clause requires for string not to include any control characters (i.e. \n or \t).

Piazza Post:3160
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-10-10T05:09:50Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3159
Subject:
Content:For me, test1.cpp was literally just a list of function calls. The autograder has some buggy functions that it will call with your test cases, and compare the outputs of your functions to the buggy output it expects to find.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3161
Poster:student
Num Views:4
Type:question
Created:2014-10-10T04:57:03Z
Tags:project3
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:confusion about "requires value to be > 0"
Content:In Project 3 while defining functions, when the RME of a function says "requires (value) to be >0", does this mean that we have to make sure while defining the function in asciiart.cpp that it works only when (value) > 0, or does it mean that the codes that the autograder runs our asciiart.cpp file with do not use negative values as input for (value)?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3162
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-10-10T05:01:26Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3161
Subject:
Content:It is the job of the function call to make sure the "Required" part of the RME is followed. The function itself shouldn't have to check the values it's being fed. So if RME says value must be > 0, the autograder will only test values > 0
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3163
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-10T05:02:35Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3161
Subject:
Content:The autograder will not use negative values as input in that case. The requires clause can be interpreted as the expected input for the function. In this case, we will not write our function to have cases for negative numbers because we should never get one.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3164
Poster:student

Subject:It's just a warning but then my test cases still will only return false so I think I need to work with my logic a little more. Thank you!
Content:I'm having a lot of trouble with the isPrime function. I've tried different nestings of a for loop and if else statements and have failed to get a good result. I guess I'm also confused as how to get it to return what I want. I think my results are incorrect because I have the returns in my for loops and they are constantly changing as my function loops but I don't know how to get them out and to return the correct consistent result. Additionally, I'm still confused after searching piazza, but is it OK to return 0s and 1s? I'm having trouble converting to trues/falses. Thanks and sorry for how late this is.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3172
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-10-10T05:36:46Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3171
Subject:
Content:I had no trouble with a single "if" statement inside a "for" statement. Basically, loop through each integer below the number you're checking. If you find a multiple of that number, return false. Otherwise, return true. Also, 1's and 0's are the correct output. That's how the computer sees true / false. I'd suggest you look at the remainder operator % if you aren't using it.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Error: make: Entering directory `/tmp/ag_grader/tmpGnyg9X' g++ -std\=c++11 -I /z/183grader/projects/F14/P3 -c asciiart.cpp asciiart.cpp: In function void printMersennePrimes(int, int): asciiart.cpp:194:23: error: pow was not declared in this scope int x = int(pow(2, i)) - 1; 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3177
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-10-10T07:41:53Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3176
Subject:
Content:I think it's the "int(" before pow. you definetly don't want to declare pow an int. have a look at the syntax from cplusplus.com example code. I'd make it: int x = pow(2, i) - 1; /* pow example */ #include <stdio.h> /* printf */ #include <math.h> /* pow */ int main () { printf ("7 ^ 3 = %f\n", pow (7.0, 3.0) ); printf ("4.73 ^ 12 = %f\n", pow (4.73, 12.0) ); printf ("32.01 ^ 1.54 = %f\n", pow (32.01, 1.54) ); return 0; }
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:3192
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-10-10T17:06:36Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3191
Subject:After putting both outputs through a difference checker, it appears that the extra numbers are a 2 (the very next number after the first long list of numbers) and a 5 (located after 5, 7).
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3193
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-10T19:19:38Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3191
Subject:
Content:The white space does not matter on this test! If under Settings in the autograder output "Whitespace: False" appears, then the autograder is not checking for whitespace differences. Check this out and then run these tests for yourself. Checking printPrimes with ranges of: non-prime to non-prime prime to prime start and end the same start is a prime, end is not start is not a prime, end is start is > end
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3194

Piazza Post:3195
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-10-10T16:59:08Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3194
Subject:
Content:If you look carefully, there is always an extra space in front of every line of the Latex examples in PROJECT 3 WEB PAGE. It's just because it's made from Latex. So do not paste the exact thing from the web page to quick diff to compare with your output. Follow your instinct. If there shouldn't be a space or an endl according to the instructions, don't put it. If possible, check to see if you are right in style grader. <image> width="218" height="254" 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Subject:Test suite failing the autograder, maybe because I forgot ?
Content:I've failed the autograder for all three submissions with feedback weeding out a stupid mistake each time, and my last feedback was this: <image> I realized I forgot to add #include <cmath> to the testing suite main function although it was at the top of my asciiart.cpp file. Would this fix the error? There are no other mistakes in the code, I have now checked it very thoroughly. Thanks for your help!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3215
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-10-10T21:07:01Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3214
Subject:
Content:I think it failed not because of not adding #include<cmath>. The reason is that both the correct asciiart.cpp and the bugged asciiart.cpp from the 183 team have included cmath so it won't cause a compile error. It failed because of KILLED_LENGTH. It means one of your cases' length is too long. As shown in an example given by the instructions: print_rectangle(123456, 1234567); Quoted from instructions: For this case, "you will never know that the results are correct. Therefore it is not useful, and it may cause a timeout on the autograder, which means you get almost no results back from the autograder and it will burn a submit. Make your testing count."
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:3224
Poster:student

Piazza Post:3228

Endorsements:0
Response To:3227
Subject:
Content:The common reason I see this error is for the following code: for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) { if (i % 2 == 0) return true; else return false; } What line of code executes if the statement i % 2 == 0 evaluates to true? What happens if that expression evaluates to false? What does return do in a function?

Piazza Post:3286
Poster:student
Num Views:3
Type:question
Created:2014-10-11T21:24:01Z
Tags:midterm_exam1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Code vs. Expression
Content:On the free response part of the exam, some of the questions ask to write "a program" or "code" or "an expression", etc. How much must be included for each? For example- which ones must include #include... int main(){... etc.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3287
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-11T21:40:37Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3286
Subject:
Content:If we ask you for a "program", we expect a fully executable program: #include <iostream> int main () { std::cout << "Hello World!" << '\n'; } If we ask you for "code" or "an expression", the following will suffice: std::cout << "Hello World!" << '\n'; or cout << "Hello World!" << endl; 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3288
Poster:student
Num Views:26
Type:question
Created:2014-10-11T21:49:55Z
Tags:zyante
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:pass by reference vs. pass by value
Content:I still don't quite understand when to use pass by value vs. pass by reference, but I understand the difference between them. In what situations do i use pass by reference, and in what situations do i use pass by value?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3289
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-12T00:01:48Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3288
Subject:
Content:Great question! So, if inside main you are hoping to alter a variable by calling a function, if you pass your variable by reference to the function, after the function is finished the new value will remain. Let's say I have a pass-by-reference function: void addTwo(int &x); Inside my main, if I have a variable int num = 0 I can change this value by saying: addTwo(num); Equivalently, if I have a pass-by-value function: int addTwo(int x); And inside my main I have the same variable num = 0 I can change this value by saying: num = addTwo(num); The only difference between the two is that my pass-by-value function makes a copy and pushes it back to the call. For the most part, you can use either, whichever one makes the most sense to you- the slight advantage of pass-by-reference functions is that they don't need to allocate extra memory just to execute the function. (For example, if I were passing a hundred doubles into a function by value, there would be 800 extra bytes of memory used just to make copies!) Hopefully this clears things up. Let's keep discussing if you want more clarification.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3290
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-10-14T03:19:52Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3288
Subject:So the only difference is that for pass by value you have to assign the answer you get from the function to another variable(ex: num); whereas if you pass by reference you don't have to. Am I correct in saying this?
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3291
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-10-14T03:41:03Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3288
Subject:in pass by value, the only way to get values out of the function is through the 'return' in pass by reference, the actual parameters can also be altered within the function and those changes are propagated back
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3292
Poster:student

Piazza Post:3293
Poster:instructor

Piazza Post:3302
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-12T10:31:51Z
Tags:
Endorsements:5
Response To:3301
Subject:
Content:I've included a course list for minor/major at UMich at the bottom of this. After 183 the next logical step in programming is to take EECS 280, which is what this course prepares you for. Most people also supplement EECS 280 with EECS 203, which covers discrete math and logic rather than programming. Another class you could take is EECS 285 (2-credit course in Java), though it's usually offered only in the fall. EECS 280 is fairly similar in difficulty to EECS 183. As with most CS courses, it's definitely manageable if you are proactive about the projects and attend class regularly. Minor in CS: EECS 183 EECS 280 EECS 203 EECS 281 MATH 115 <elective> Major in CS: EECS 183 EECS 280 EECS 203 EECS 281 EECS 370 EECS 376 MATH 115 MATH 116 <capstone> <elective>

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3345
Poster:student
Num Views:3
Type:question
Created:2014-10-13T03:57:09Z
Tags:midterm_exam1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:F09 exam1 question
Content:11. Given the following code fragment, what prints if the user types 3.5 + 3.5 and presses enter/return at the standard input? Note that there is a space before and after +. int x, z; char y; cin >> x >> y >> z; cout << x + z; a) 5 b) 6 c) 7 *d) 8 e) none of the above can someone explain more about why the answer is d? Thanks!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3346
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-13T04:44:43Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3345
Subject:
Content:This is how cin works. It reads characters from the terminal into "x", which is an integer. The first time it encounters a ".", it stops reading x. So, x = 3. Next, char "y" is assigned the '.' character. So, y = '.' Finally, "z" is read from the console, until a whitespace is encountered. So, z = 5. That means, x + z = 3 + 5 = 8.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3347
Poster:student
Num Views:45
Type:question
Created:2014-10-13T16:03:00Z
Tags:midterm_exam1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:W12 Exam 2 question
Content:10.Consider the following code fragment: int a[5] = {1,2,3,4,5}; int i = 1; a[i++] = 6; a[++i] = 7; cout << a[0] << a[1] << a[2] << a[3] << a[4]; What does the above code fragment print? a) 62745 *b) 16375 (I don't understand how this is the answer) c) 16745 d) 12675 e) 67345
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3348
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-13T16:16:11Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3347
Subject:
Content:This question comes down to understanding how exactly i++ vs. ++i works. Both increment the value of i, but i++ returns the value of i before incrementing whereas ++i returns the value after i has been incremented. Therefore: a[i++] = 6; // this is equal to a[1], i is = 2 afterwards a[++i] = 7; // this is equal to a[3], i was 2 to begin with, but was incremented to 3 before being returned 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3349
Poster:student
Num Views:39
Type:question
Created:2014-10-13T16:17:31Z
Tags:midterm_exam1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:W10 MR questons
Content:13. Which of the following calls to the function process are valid, if process has the function prototype: void process(char y);? Select all choices that apply. A) process('A'); B) cout << process('A'); C) x = process('A'); D) process("A"); Can anyone tell me why c is not the answer? 17. Consider the following code fragment: if ((3 == 4) && (3 /0 == 4)) cout << "true" << endl; else cout << "false" << endl; What does the above code print? A) false B) true C) the above code causes a division by zero error D) none of the above why not c? 20. What is the 1st line printed? #include<iostream> using namespace std; int main() { int today = 10, examday = 10; bool i_studied = false; if(i_studied) if(today == examday) cout << "I'll do fine \n"; else cout << "I should have studied and not read blogs!\n "; cout << "Thank You, Stroustrup!\n"; return 0; } A) I'll do fine B) I should have studied and not read blogs! C) Thank You, Stroustrup D) none of the above Why not A?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3350
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-13T16:28:13Z
Tags:
Endorsements:2
Response To:3349
Subject:
Content:13: The function's return type is void. We cannot assign a variable to the function's return value, because there would be no return value. 17: We first check the expression, "3 == 4." Since this is false and we have an && expression, the "3/0 == 4" is never evaluated. With an && expression, both values on either side of it must be true. If the first is not, the second does not need to be evaluated. 20: cout << "I'll do fine \n"; belongs to if(today == exam day) which is nested inside of if(i_studied). However, i_studied is false so we never check if(today == exam day). if(i_studied) // false, so we don't get to the following 2 lines if(today == exam day) cout << "I'll do fine \n"; 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3351
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-10-13T16:32:39Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3349
Subject:
Content:For 13, in C in the variable x is being assigned to a function call that returns nothing (void) . You would be assigning a variable to nothing practically. For 17, I'm not sure. It could be because you are testing a condition and not assigning a variable to a divide by zero fraction. For 23, the first if-statement is false, therefore the inner if and else statements are not executed. You then would move onto the next line outside the if statement, which would print "Thank You, Stroustrup" Hope this helped!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3352
Poster:student
Num Views:10
Type:question
Created:2014-10-13T16:35:26Z
Tags:midterm_exam1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:F12 Exam 2 Question
Content:10) Consider the following code (read carefully!): // REQUIRES: The size of the array is length; length >= 1 int maxLevel(const int levels[], int length) { int maximum = levels[0]; for (int i = 1; i < length; i += 1) { if (levels[i] > maximum) { return levels[i]; } else { return maximum; } } return maximum; } const int SIZE = 5; int herp[SIZE] = { 1, 6, 18, 3, 9001 }; What does maxLevel(herp, SIZE) return? A) 9001 B) 1 *C) 6 (why is this the answer?) D) 0 E) 18
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3353
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:s_answer
Created:2014-10-13T16:41:58Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3352
Subject:
Content:The problem with that is that when a function hits a return statement, it doesn't carry out the rest of the function. So basically, in this example, the function compares herp[1] (which is 6) to herp[0] (which is 1, aka the current value of maximum), sees that 6 is greater, and returns 6, without bothering to the check the rest of the numbers. All this function is doing is returning the FIRST number that's greater than the first value in the array, not the ACTUAL maximum.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3354
Poster:student
Num Views:12
Type:question

Piazza Post:3356
Poster:student
Num Views:9
Type:question
Created:2014-10-13T17:18:01Z
Tags:midterm_exam1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:W10 FR question
Content:price = 0.0; str1 = "one"; str2 = "two"; getline(cin, str1); cin >> price ; getline(cin, str2); cout << str1 << endl << price << endl << str2 << endl; input: Bidder1 42.15 Bidder2 why output is : Bidder1 42.15 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3357
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-13T18:53:50Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3356
Subject:
Content:Try it out in Xcode or Visual Studio. The first getline will get "Bidder1", cin will get 42.15, and the next getline will capture the remaining characters on the line with 42.15 line. This is because cin stops at whitespace so there is still an endline character '\n' on that line that the last getline will get. Look back at projects 1 and 2 where you used both cin and getline. Understand why you used one over the other in different cases.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:3359

Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-13T19:08:12Z

Endorsements:1
Response To:3358
Subject:
Content:Mine displays the correct time. You may need to set your Google Calendar to the correct timezone. Go to google.com/calendar, click the gear icon on the right side, and check the timezone field. It should be set to (GMT -5.00) Eastern. If you have multiple Google accounts (ex: U-M account and a @gmail.com account), you might want to check those accounts as well.

Response To:-1
Subject:F10 MC question
Content:7. Which of the following variable declarations will compile? a) double FOObar(); b) double myFavoriteNumber66; c) int 1ForAll; d) char _my_character; e) b & d why the answer is e not the others?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3361
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-13T18:46:12Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3360
Subject:
Content:A: Is actually a valid way to declare a variable however you must provide the value of the double within the parentheses. So, in this case: double FOObar(1.0); But, since we don't have a value, it won't compile. C: You can't start variable name with a number.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3362
Poster:student
Num Views:3
Type:question
Created:2014-10-13T18:08:29Z
Tags:midterm_exam1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:F09 MC question
Content:9. Given the following code fragment, what prints? cout << "\\\"; // Is this a comment?"; a) \ b) \"; // Is this a comment? c) \\\"; // Is this a comment? d) \\ e) \\\ I'm confusing about this question. if "\"" will print ", the code will print "\\"; // Is this a comment?". b misses a "\"
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3363
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-13T19:02:41Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3362
Subject:
Content:Since it itself is used to escape characters, if we actually want to print the backslash character, '\', we must also escape it. That's what's happening here. The first two backslashes print one backslash. cout << "\""; --> " The 3rd backslash escapes the following quote. cout << "\\"; --> \
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Response To:-1
Subject:F12 EXAM 1 MC question
Content:7. int x = 2, y = 4; char ch; cin >> x; cin. get (ch); cin >> y; cout << x * y; if the user types the following at standard input, what does the above code fragment print? 2*2<enter> A) 4 B)5 C) 6 D) 8 E) 10 why is the answer D) instead of A) I thought that x would be 2, ch = * and then y = 2 as well. Would you please help me understand? Thank you!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3374
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-14T01:37:18Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3373
Subject:
Content:int x = 2, y = 4; char ch; cin >> x; <--- x reads in 2 cin. get (ch); <--- get reads the next character and this character is a space cin >> y; <--- tries to read an int and finds a '*'. cin goes into a fail states, so y is not overwritten cout << x * y; <--- so this will output an 8 note we haven't covered fail sates yet and what happens if a stream goes into a fail state
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3375
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-10-14T01:43:06Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3373
