Assuming the code is cin >> x >> ch >> y and the input it 2 * 2 as well, why is ch = * instead of space in this scenario? Is there anything special about the cin.get? Thanks!
Content:None

Poster:instructor

Subject:because the input is 2 * 2 and cin.get(ch) gets the next character in the input stream >> skips whitespace get does not

Piazza Post:3379
Poster:student
Num Views:2
Type:question
Created:2014-10-14T04:57:38Z
Tags:codelab
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:codelab 11092
Content:For convenience's sake this is problem 11092: Write the definition of a function <link> named rotate4ints that is passed four <link> int <link> variables . The function returns nothing but rotates the <link> values of the four<link> variables : the first <link> variable , gets the <link> value of the last of the four, the second gets the <link> value of the first, the third the <link> value of the second, and the last (fourth)<link> variable gets the <link> value of the third. So, if i , j , k , and m have (respectively) the <link> values 15, 47, 6 and 23, and the invocation rotate4ints(i,j,k,m) is made, then upon return, the <link> values of i , j , k , and m will be 23, 15, 47 and 6 respectively. I understand how to get the correct answer using the pass by reference method (I have int variables &a/&b/&c/&d). I use a temporary integer called "e" in the function definition as a placeholder. Pseudocode: rotate4ints (&a, &b, &c, &d) { set e = d temporarily swap the other four variables: d = c, c = b, b = a, a = e } However, can someone explain why a pass by value would NOT work? In pass by value, don't the parameters (a/b/c/d) retain their original values? So that I wouldn't even need temporary variable e in order to swap the four? 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3380
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-14T05:32:04Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3379
Subject:
Content:you need 4 values altered. The only way to get any value out of pass by value is through the "return" statement and that will return exactly one. So how do you alter 4 values?
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:3383
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-14T14:11:44Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3382
Subject:
Content:usually no unless we really under estimate the difficulty of the exam. We shoot for an average of about 75 - 80%. If the average comes in significantly below this, we would make exam 2 easier. In the many years I have taught this course, we have had to do this exactly once.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3384
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-10-14T14:58:43Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3382
Subject:Is it still possible get a good grade in the class if we do not do well on exams?
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3385
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-10-14T15:11:53Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3382
Subject:The phrases "good grade" and "do not do well" are highly subjective. The exams are 50% of your final grade, so not "doing well" on half the course will certainly reduce your expected grade. From the course materials also consider the following: "Note: you must have a project average of at least 50% and an exam average of at least 50% to pass the course." So, in the event you were to score 100% on all non-exam grades and 49.9% on exams, you would accumulate 749 of 1000 points (which is typically a "C" grade) but would fail the course.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3386
Poster:student
Num Views:None

Created:2014-10-14T15:15:28Z

Piazza Post:3387

Type:question
Created:2014-10-14T13:44:56Z
Tags:midterm_exam1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:W12 Exam 1
Content:7 If the user types: 1 1<ENTER>, what does the following code snippet output? char a, b; cin >> a; cin.get(b); cout << (a == b); A) 1 B) 0 (How do you get 0 as the answer?) C) a D) a == b E) None of the above 10 What does the following C++ program print? (read carefully) #include <iostream> using namespace std; int main() { int x = 3; if (x = 0) cout << "Am I here?"; else if (x == 3) cout << "Or here?"; return 0; } A) Am I here? B) Or here? C) Am I here?Or here? D) This code contains syntax errors and will not compile. E) It will run with no errors, but print nothing. (Why does nothing print?)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3388
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-14T14:07:42Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3387
Subject:
Content:If the user types: 1 1, what does the following code snippet output? char a, b; cin >> a; cin.get(b); cout << (a == b); Note that the input is: 1 1 cin >> a; <--- reads the first 1 cin.get(b) <--- gets the next char -- this would be the space cout << (a == b) '1' is not equal to ' ' also note that we have NOT gone over the get command yet so it will NOT be on Exam 1 #include using namespace std; int main() { int x = 3; if (x = 0) <--- this assigns 0 to x cout << "Am I here?"; <--- doesn't go here because 0 evaluates to false else if (x == 3) <--- this also evaluates to false because x is now 0 cout << "Or here?"; return 0; }
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:3392
Poster:student
Num Views:6
Type:question
Created:2014-10-14T17:15:10Z
Tags:midterm_exam1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:W13 MC Exam Questions
Content:1) Why is the answer 7? If the user types: 3.5 * 2.5 <ENTER>, what does the following code snippet output? double x; int y; char ch; cin >> x >> ch >> y; cout << x * y; 2) Why is the answer "No"? If the user inputs: 2<ENTER>, what does the following code snippet print? (read carefully) char x; cin >> x; if (x == 1) { cout << "Yes"; } else if (x == 2) { cout << "Maybe"; } else { cout << "No"; } 3) Why is the answer A and not All of the Above (A B & C)? Which of the following is a valid declaration of a function that accepts three auction bids and returns the minimum of them: A) double getMin(double a, double b, double c); B) int getMin(int a, int b, int c); C) int getMin(double a, double b, double c); D) Both B and C are correct E) None of the above 4) Why is 282 printed rather than 288? What is printed? int cube(int x); int main() { int x = 2; cout << x; cube(x); cout << x; return 0; } int cube(int x) { x = x * x * x; cout << x; return x; }
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3393
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-14T17:43:18Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3392
Subject:
Content:1. See the explanation in @1136. Just remember that for this problem, x is a double. 2. x is a char, here. That means x == '2', but x != 2 (the integer) 3. Auction bids are made with money, which has dollars and cents. Because of the cents (meaning decimal value), the function's arguments as well as its return type must be doubles. 4. x is being passed by value to the function cube(). This means that the value of x is unchanged after the function call. It would be 288 if the line: cube(x) instead said: x = cube(x) It would also change if the header of the cube function were: int cube(int& x){ 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:3404
Poster:instructor
Num Views:25
Type:note
Created:2014-10-15T03:18:56Z
Tags:logistics
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Office Hours Changes
Content:Hello everyone, We are making several changes to office hours starting tomorrow (Wednesday 10/15). We hope these changes will allow all students equal access to office hours, as well as reduce wait times. These changes are also intended to help you develop your independent problem solving skills. As the semester progresses, you are expected to be able to solve more problems independently and we think our changes will help facilitate this transition. Beginning tomorrow, you will be limited to being helped 3 times at office hours per day. Do keep in mind, your partner is also able to sign up three times per day. Please use this as encouragement to start the projects as early as possible. You will also have to wait 15 minutes after being helped before you can sign up again. This is to give you a chance to make new progress on your own after being helped. We will also no longer allow you to write code for your projects while we are helping you. The projects are where you get to demonstrate your understanding of the course content. If you need help with a project, you will need to think of a specific question we can answer. If you have any questions or concerns about these changes, please post on Piazza or send an email to 183.admin@umich.edu
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3405
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-10-15T04:39:37Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3404
Subject:Please explain this: "We will also no longer allow you to write code for your projects while we are helping you." This does not make sense to me. What am I missing?
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3406
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-10-15T05:40:11Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3404
Subject:Basically, it means we won't help you while you're writing code for your project. We'll answer questions about your code, but won't sit next to you while you're writing the code. Does that make sense? We will gladly answer concept questions; we will gladly help you figure out where a bug is; we will gladly answer questions concerning your code. However on many occasions a student will ask about a function and instead of listening to the response and trying to understand what is going on, they just write code to get it done. This is not really helpful to the student because they still will not understand. This is what we will no longer do.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3407
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:feedback
Created:2014-10-15T18:56:43Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3404
Subject:Here's a very rudimentary (but hopefully clear) example of what we mean. Student: "I don't understand how to print separate lines of stars." IA: "Well what kind of C++ tool have you learned about in lecture to do something N number of times?" S: "A for loop" *writes for (int i = in their project* S: "So what should I assign to i? What should it be compared with?" We won't sit there and say "Well you should assign it 0 and run while i < N." We don't want to tell you how to write the code or what code to write specifically, that's your job as a student in a programming course. However, we are MORE than happy to talk about a general algorithm ("if this is true, then you need to do this, otherwise you need to do something else x times"), help with debugging, or understanding course content/syntax. The point is, we will be there to facilitate the "what is it this thing should do" and you will be responsible for the "how it will do this." Hopefully that is helpful in clearing that up for you in case you wanted a specific example of what we mean.
Content:None
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:3422
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-15T18:45:39Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3421
Subject:
Content:Please include the question itself when posting about CodeLab (as stated in @6). As for the feedback, it usually gives you examples that CodeLab runs, listing what your result was and what the final result should have been. In terms of corner cases, some possibilities to think about are: what happens if you insert into an array of size 0? Size 1? An array that is already at its maximum capacity?

Piazza Post:3423
Poster:student
Num Views:2
Type:question
Created:2014-10-15T18:19:06Z
Tags:midterm_exam1, zyante
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Initializing maxVal (Zyante 6.4)
Content:I was re-reading the sections about arrays, and came across a contradiction... <image> Could someone clarify what the book means? Thank you!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3424
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-15T18:29:54Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3423
Subject:
Content:Actually, what is happening is when maxVal is created they are initializing it (which is VERY good practice). However, if you look further down in the code you will see that they "initialize" maxVal to the first element of the array. The sentence directly preceding the one you're pointing out also explicitly states "Before entering the loop, maxVal must be initialized..." meaning they are pointing out a common bug that happens if you don't "re-initialize." But an easier way to do this would be to actually declare maxVal when it is assigned userVals[0].
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Piazza Post:3427

Num Views:16
Type:question
Created:2014-10-15T20:07:25Z
Tags:midterm_exam1
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:Question 13 and 14 in Winter 2012 Exam
Content:As stated in the summary, my question is about the two problems in the exam. THIS QUESTION WILL EXPOSE THE ANSWERS sorry :( Question #13 Consider the following code fragment: cout << "\\\"; // Is this a comment?"; The answer is \"; // Is this a comment? I know that \\ gives a backslash but I don't get how // doesn't make the rest of the line a comment. Question #14 Consider the following C++ functions: bool t() { cout << 't'; return true; } bool f() { cout << 'f'; return false; } void m() { if ((t() && f()) || (t() || f())) { cout << 'm'; } } The answer is d) tftm t() returns true and f() returns false, so the only way to get that answer is that even though the first logical expression (t() && (f()) ultimately returns false, it still prints out its output. Does that mean that whatever it outputs is independent on whether the overall expression is true or false? Thanks for your help!
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3428
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-15T22:49:11Z
Tags:
Endorsements:1
Response To:3427
Subject:
Content:1st: cout << "//" will print: // // has no significance as an escape sequence for comments when it is inside quotes, since it's just a string in that case. 2nd: Read up on "short-circuit evaluation" t() && f() || t() || t() will evaluate as true && false || true || true Some other IA will need to flesh this out for me, since I have to relocate right now :) 
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3429
Poster:student
Num Views:None
Type:followup
Created:2014-10-15T23:38:57Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3427
Subject:I get the first question now. \* would print a double quote, so the comment is actually inside the cout function. Thanks!
Content:None

Subject:getline(cin, str); and cin.get(ch);
Content:I'm looking at Questions 7 and 8 in the Fall 2012 exam, and I have a question about these two functions(?). If the code writes (Question 7): int x = 2, y =4; char ch; cin >> x; cin.get(ch); cin >> y; cout << x * y; The user types "2 * 2 <Enter>" The value 2 is assigned to x, and the rest of the line has 4 "characters", so 4 is assigned to cin.get(ch) I think. Does that mean that whatever is implemented in cin.get(ch) is also given to y? The other example is Question 8: int x = 2, y = 4; string str; cin >> x; getline(cin, str); cin >> y; cout << x * y; If the user types 2 <Enter> 3 <Enter> 4 <Enter> 2 is assigned to x, and 3 is assigned to getline(cin,str), but based on the answer, 4 is not assigned to y, but instead the value of getline(cin,str) which is 3 is assigned to y, so the answer is 2 * 3 = 6. Do these two functions basically assign their values to the following cin? Thanks again :)

Piazza Post:3436

Tags:midterm_exam1, unanswered
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:W11 Exam 1 12 and 28
Content:12. Given a bool variable isFull, which of the following is a valid C++ assignment statement? A. isFull = true; B. isFull = isFull || ceil(2.4) % 2 + 1 == 3; C. isFull = 2 < 3 + 2 < 20 - 5; D. all of the above E. none of the above The answer is D. I don't understand why B and C are correct? How can you use the same variable in assigning the variable, and how do interpret the expressions in C? 28. What value gets printed by the program? #include <iostream> int main( ) { int x = 0; int y = 0; if (x++ && y++) { y += 2; } cout << x + y << endl; return 0; } A. 1 B. 2 C. 3 D. 4 E. Undefined Since x++ and y++ are both arithmetic expressions, they should both evaluate to true, which means y will be incremented by 2. But since there are no parentheses around x+y in the cout statement, only x is printed, which is why the answer is A, correct?

Piazza Post:3439
Poster:student
Num Views:6
Type:question
Created:2014-10-16T02:21:49Z
Tags:codelab
Endorsements:0
Response To:-1
Subject:11191
Content:I can't seem to get this one in code lab right! I believe I have successfully reordered the array, and found the median but for one of the test cases, there are 6 elements, and the median two are 3 and 4. My code assigns m = 4, however the correct answer is m = 3. How do I prevent the average from rounding up since it returns an int? (I attempted to use floor but code lab said it was not necessary) You are <link> given an <link> array x of <link> int <link> elements along with an <link> int <link> variable n that contains the number of <link> elements in the <link> array . There are no duplicates in this <link> array . You are also <link> given an <link> int <link> variable m that has been <link> declared . Assign to m the median<link> value of the <link> array .
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Piazza Post:3440
Poster:instructor
Num Views:None
Type:i_answer
Created:2014-10-16T04:12:48Z
Tags:
Endorsements:0
Response To:3439
Subject:
Content:According to the question's prompt, If the set has an even number of members, the median is the average of the pair of numbers such that there are as many numbers above the pair as there are below. So you'll need to find the average of ( arr[size/2] + arr[size/2 + 1] ) / 2 :) If you have trouble with integer division, remember to static_cast<double>(size/2)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
